Change User Profile
The Change User Profile pages pertain to the function used for changing the password and e-mail address of the logged-on user. It is accessed through CE User link on the landing page.
This function consists of two types of pages: change user profile page and confirmation page.
 NOTE: The user password can also be changed using the I Forgot My Password link provided in the Logon Page. Refer to the Logon Page > Resetting Password section for information on this procedure.
  Change User Profile Page
  The Change User Profile page consists of two sections: Change Password and Change Email. This page is defined in this file –
  [WEB SERVER DRIVE]\screen\SYS_UserProfile.jsp
  Each section is provided with a set of Reset and Confirm buttons that are used for resetting and confirming the password and the e-mail address, respectively.
  The following table outlines the Change User Profile page buttons and the corresponding methods performed.
    Button Name Change Password Change Email     RESET OnInit() initEmailBox()   CONFIRM Confirm() confirmEmail()     NOTE: Clicking on the Change Password – Confirm button only saves the new password even when a new e-mail is specified (in the Change Email section). In order to modify the e-mail address, access the Change User Profile Page again, change the e-mail address, and click on the Change Email – Confirm button.
        Figure 3. 26 Change User Profile Page
 NOTE: The password of the CE user must conform to the following rules:
   It must be at least 8-characters long.
  It must contain an uppercase character, a lowercase character, and a digit.
  It must not contain any special characters.
  It must not contain more than three consecutive digits or more than three consecutive identical characters.
  It must not contain the user account or name.
  It must not be the same as recently used passwords.
   Confirmation Page
  The confirmation page is the page that is displayed if the change password or change e-mail process is successful.
  It is defined in this file –
  [WEB SERVER DRIVE]\screen\SYS_UserModiOK.jsp
        Figure 3. 27 Confirmation Page
Function Tools
Some of the function tools used in the CE system are the clause, lookup button (Inquire CUBK), transaction template, and calendar.
 Clause Page
  The clause page in a transaction function pertains to the popup window that allows the end-user of the system to select predefined clauses as input for the transaction. (It is displayed by clicking on a corresponding button on the transaction screen.)
  The clause page is defined in this file –
  [WEB SERVER DRIVE]\[BANK]\[COUNTRY]\WEB\CLAUSE\ClauseMain.jsp
        Figure 3. 28 Clause Page
 Inquire CUBK
  The Inquire CUBK page in a transaction function pertains to the popup window that allows the end-user to select a record which details populate transaction fields as input. (It is displayed by clicking on a corresponding lookup button on the transaction screen.)
  The Inquire CUBK page is defined in this file –
  [WEB SERVER DRIVE]\screen\SYS_InqCUBK.jsp
  The following table outlines the buttons used in the Inquire CUBK page as well as the corresponding JavaScript files and methods performed.
    Button Name File Name JS Function Name     CANCEL N/A self.close()   Filter screen\SYS_InqCUBK.jsp on_search_click()   Reset screen\SYS_InqCUBK.jsp ReSetGetData()           Figure 3. 29 Inquire CUBK Page
 Transaction Template
  The template page in a transaction function pertains to the popup window that allows the end-user of the system to either:
   Save the current transaction data as a template that can be retrieved for future transactions; or
  Load an existing template which details are to be used in the current transaction.
The template page is defined in this file –
[WEB SERVER DRIVE]\screen\SYS_CE_Template.jsp
The following table outlines the buttons used in a template page, as well as the corresponding JavaScript files and methods performed.
     Button Name File Name JS Function Name     CANCEL N/A parent.close()   CREATE screen\SYS_CE_Template_Content.jsp TmplSubmit(document.MAINFORM.TemplateName.value,‘INSERT’)   LOAD screen\SYS_CE_Template_Content.jsp TmplSubmit(GetIdValue(document.MAINFORM.TmplID),‘LOADING’)   UPDATE screen\SYS_CE_Template_Content.jsp TmplSubmit(GetIdValue(document.MAINFORM.TmplID),‘UPDATE’)   DELETE screen\SYS_CE_Template_Content.jsp TmplSubmit(GetIdValue(document.MAINFORM.TmplID),‘DELETE’)     NOTE: When the Template button is clicked from the first tab of the transaction function page, the Load button is displayed in the Template Page. When clicked from the last tab, the Create button is displayed instead of the Load button.
        Figure 3. 30 Template Page
 Calendar
  In certain Date fields, a dropdown calendar is provided for selecting a specific date. (This is displayed upon clicking on the accompanying calendar icon.)
  The Calendar functionality is defined in this file –
  [WEB SERVER DRIVE]\JS\Calendar.js
        Figure 3. 31 Calendar
Main Menu
Main Menu
The main menu is the common way by which a function is accessed and run. (Another way is through the inbox.)
The L&F of the main menu varies according to the bank requirements.
   Figure 4. 1 Example 1 Figure 4. 2 Example 2          Figure 4. 3 Example 3
Creating the Main Menu
The overall functionality of the main menu is defined in these JS files.
   JS File Description     \SYS_JS\ SYS_menu.js This contains the codes for building or designing the main menu.   \SYS_JS\ SYS_menu_event.js This contains the codes running the functions in the main menu.    To change the L&F of the main menu:
  Create a standalone JS file for building the main menu as required.
  Declare this standalone JS file in the transaction screens. Make sure that the SYS_menu.js file is removed from the codes
  Declare the SYS_menu_event.js file in all the transaction screens or in the Common.jsp file:
  Generating the Main Menu
The Function Access Permission (FAP) of the CE user, assigned in the Security Module, determines the type of menu to be created for the user. Specifically, a JavaScript data array is generated.
Declare <CETAGS:GetMenuArray/> files located in the following directory:
 [WEB SERVER DRIVE]\ Templates
 The data array, strArray, contains the following parameters:
   Array Index Parameter Description Example     0 Module This refers to the 4-character module name. SECU   1 Product Id This refers to the product Id. P06031300000   2 Product Name This refers to the product name. Authorization User Rule by Function   3 Function Id This refers to the function Id. F05030700553   4 Function name This refers to the function name. Add Auth User Rule by Func   5 Item Id This refers to the item Id. New   6 Item Name This refers to the item name. New   7 Product Type This refers to the product type – ‘S’ (Security) or ‘T’ (Transaction).    8 New/Cata This refers to the type of screen produced when a product is clicked: a new (initiation) screen or a catalog screen. This is now supported in CE V2.1.0.    9 Catalog Number This refers to the number of catalogs in the catalog screen. As this is currently not supported in CE V2.1.0, the value is: 1.    10 Module Description This refers to the description of the module. Security Module   11 Product Description This refers to the description of the product. Operator Class Maintain   12 Function Description This refers to the description of the function. Add Operator Class    The strArray data array generated follows this format:
[“[MODULE]”, “[PRODUCT ID]”, “[PRODUCT NAME]”, “[FUNCTION ID]”, “[FUNCTION NAME]”, “[ITEM ID]”, “[ITEM NAME]”, “[PRODUCT TYPE]”, “[NEW/CATA]”, “[CATALOG NUMBER]”. “[MODULE DESCRIPTION]”, “[PRODUCT DESCRIPTION]”]
EXAMPLE:
[“IMLC”,“P08071500000”,“Import Letters of Credit”,“F05030700829”,“Apply for Import LC”,“New”,“New”,“T”,“new”,“1”,“Import Letters of Credit”,“Import Letters of Credit”,“Apply for Import LC”]
       Figure 4. 4 Example of an HTML Source Code
This JavaScript file contains the commands for creating the main menu, and may be modified to produce different menu styles: [WEB SERVER DRIVE]\JS\MainMenu.js. Refer also to Chapter Eight > MainMenu.js discussion for sample content of the MainMenu.js file.
Running a Menu Function
When a user selects a function from the main menu, the onClick() event of the main menu is executed. Depending on the project involved, either of the following functions has to be called in order to execute this event:
  funcItemClick (modDesc, pdtID, funcID, itemID, modName)
  _funcItemClick(sSelectedFuncId)
  These methods are defined in the following file –
 [WEB SERVER DRIVE]\SYS_JS\SYS_menu_event.js
        Figure 4. 5 SYS_menu_event.js File
System CSS Classes
System CSS Classes
For system purposes such as field validation and date formatting, system CSS classes are provided. These CSS classes are located in the following directory: [WEB SERVER DIRECTORY]/theme
Each of the fields in the JSP screen, including hidden fields, must be assigned a valid system CSS class, the naming rule of the which is: [DATA TYPE]_[FIELD TYPE].
The following table lists the available system CSS classes.
   Class Name Description Example     AMT_M Mandatory amount field LC Amount   AMT_O Optional amount field Finance Amount   AMT_P Protected amount field LC Balance   INT_M Mandatory integer field Tenor Days   INT_O Optional integer field Positive Tolerance   INT_P Protected integer field Amendment No   FLOAT_M Mandatory float field Interest Rate   FLOAT_O Optional float field Interest Rate   FLOAT_P Protected float field Interest Rate   CHAR_M Mandatory character field Beneficiary Name   CHAR_O Optional character field Beneficiary ID   CHAR_P Protected character field Collection Reference No   DATE_M Mandatory date field Expiry Date   DATE_O Optional date field Tenor Start Date   DATE_P Protected date field Issued Date   TIME_M Mandatory time field Transaction Time   TIME_O Optional time field Registration Time   TIME_P Protected time field Login Time           Figure 5. 1 Example of a CSS File
Using Other CSS Files
The system CSS files provided can be modified as required. Aside from these, project-designed CSS files can also be used. These are also saved in the same directory where the system CSS files are located.
FTL Files
FTL Files
Freemarker Template (FTL) files are templates that can be embedded into the JSP file. These are used to generate text and define the look and feel of pages in a transaction screen.
By modifying the related FTL files, the L&F of screens that are generated by CE tags such as GetTranCata can be defined or changed. All FTL files are stored in the following directories:
  [WEB SERVVER DRIVE]\WEB-INF\FTL
  [WEB SERVVER DRIVE]\Templates\FTL
  The following are the available FTL files that can be modified according to business or functional requirements:

Example: Changing the L&F of CE
The CE user interface can be changed by modifying the files and parameters discussed in the previous chapters.
Changing the Header of the Logon Page
   Do the following . . .       1. Design the image file for the header of the logon page using an image editing software. Make sure that the relevant image is saved as a JPG file.            2. Save the image file in the following directory: [WEB SERVER DRIVE]/Images          3. The change is reflected on the logon page of the system.      Changing the Body of the Logon Page
   Do the following . . .       1. Design the image file for the body of the logon page using an image editing software. Make sure that the relevant image is saved as a PNG file.            Design the image file for the button on the logon page using an image editing software. Make sure that the relevant image is saved as a GIF file.          2. Save the image files in the following directory: [WEB SERVER DRIVE]/Images          3. The changes are reflected on the logon page of the system.      Changing the Header of the Landing Page
   Do the following . . .       1. Design the image file for the header of the landing page using an image editing software. Make sure that the image is saved as a JPG file.            2. Save the image file in the following directory: [WEB SERVER DRIVE]/Images          3. The change is reflected on the landing page of the system      Changing the Body of the Landing Page
   Do the following . . .       1. Design the image file for the body of the landing page using an image editing software. Make sure that the image is saved as a JPG file.            2. Save the image file in the following directory: [WEB SERVER DRIVE]/Images          3. The change is reflected on the landing page of the system          This is also reflected in all transaction processing and standing data functions.          This is also reflected in all the security functions.      Changing the Menu Style of the Landing Page
   Do the following . . .       MODIFYING THE BACKROUND 1. Design the image file for the main menu of the system using an image editing software. Make sure that the image is saved as a JPG file.            2. Save the image file in the following directory: [WEB SERVER DRIVE]/Images          3. The change is reflected in the main menu of the system          MODIFYING THE STYLE OF THE FUNCTIONS IN THE MAIN MENU The style of functions in the main menu can also be changed as required. Access the Standard.css file. Add the relevant CSS codes to modify the border element for all the functions. This change is reflected in the list of functions in the main menu. /**
* for generating main menu
*/
/**
* Data array in strArray
* [0 module][1 product id][2 name(?)][3 function id][4 function name][5 item id]
* [6 item name][7 product type(S or T)][8 new type][9 cata num][10 module description]
* [11 product description] [12 function description]
*/
//Global variables
var nNoOfFuncs = 0; // number of functions
var sSelectedProdId = “"; //Selected product id
var sSelectedFuncId = “"; //Selected function id
/**
* call showMainMenu() in the end of JSP
*/
function showMainMenu(){
try {
if (!window.strArray) {
showMsg(“The FAP is invalid.", “There was a problem login in.");
return;
}
//PRODUCT_ID is in catalog and trx
if (window.PRODUCT_ID && window.PRODUCT_ID.length > 0) {
sSelectedProdId = PRODUCT_ID;
}
//get function id for catalog and transaction screen
if (window.selFuncDesc && window.selFuncDesc.length > 0 && window.selFuncDesc != “null” && window.PRODUCT_ID) {
sSelectedFuncId = getFuncIdByFuncDesc(selFuncDesc)
}
var b = document.getElementById(“ProdMenu”);
if(b){ genMainMenu(b)}
}
catch (a) {
showExcpt(“MainMenu”, a)
}
}
var hiddenProdArray=[];
var hiddenFuncArray=[];
function inHiddenProdArray(b){
for(var a=0;a<hiddenProdArray.length;a++){
if(b==hiddenProdArray[a])
{return true}}return false}
function inHiddenFuncArray(d,e){
for(var b=0;b<hiddenFuncArray.length;b++)
{if(d==hiddenFuncArray[b][0])
{var c=hiddenFuncArray[b][1];
for(var a=0;a<c.length;a++){if(e==c[a])
{return true}}}}return false
}
function genMainMenu(b){
try {
if (!window.strArray) {
showMsg(“The FAP is invalid.", “There was a problem login in.");
return;
}
//init variable
if (LOGIN_NAME && LOGIN_NAME == “A”) {
isSEC = true;
}
else {
isSEC = false;
}
nNoOfFuncs = strArray.length;
genProdTable(b);
}
catch (a) {
showExcpt(“MainMenu”, a);
}
}
/**
* Generate product table
*
*/
function genProdTable(f){
try {
//drop product menu table
if (f.firstChild) {
f.removeChild(f.firstChild);
}
//create product menu table and append to product menu table cell
var b = document.createElement(“table”);
b.setAttribute(“id”, “ProdMenuTable”);
b.setAttribute(“cellspacing”, “0”);
b.setAttribute(“cellpadding”, “0”);
b.className = “ProdItem”;
f.appendChild(b);
//create product menu table tbody
var d = document.createElement(“tbody”);
d.setAttribute(“id”, “ProdMenuTableBody”);
b.appendChild(d);
var a = f.id;
//create product rows in product menu table
genProdRow(d, a)
}
catch (c) {
showExcpt(“MainMenu”, c);
}
}
/**
* Generate product rows
*/
function genProdRow(d, k){
try {
var a = new Array();
var p = new Array();
for (var h = 0; h < nNoOfFuncs; h++) {
var r = strArray[h][1];
var g = strArray[h][11];
if (!p.in_array(g)) {
a.push(r);
p.push(g);
}
}
//add product row
var c = p.length;
for (var f = 0; f < c; f++) {
if(inHiddenProdArray(a[f])){continue}
var q = document.createElement(“tr”);
var b = “row_” + a[f];
q.setAttribute(“id”, b);
var l = document.createElement(“td”);
var o = “cell_” + a[f];
l.setAttribute(“id”, o);
var m = document.createElement(“a”);
m.setAttribute(“id”, a[f]);
m.setAttribute(“pid”, k);
m.href = “#";
//set class to SelectedProdLink
if (a[f] == sSelectedProdId) {
m.className = “SelectedProdLink”
}
else {
m.className = “ProdLink”
}
m.innerHTML = p[f];
m.onclick = getProdIdOnClick;
l.appendChild(m);
q.appendChild(l);
d.appendChild(q);
//show selected product functions
if (sSelectedProdId.length > 0 && sSelectedProdId == a[f]) {
genProdFunc(d, sSelectedProdId);
}
}
}
catch (e) {
showExcpt(“MainMenu”, e)
}
}
/**
* Generate produc functions table
*/
function genProdFunc(k, h){
try {
var m = h;
var c = new Array();
//function id under this product
for (var g = 0; g < nNoOfFuncs; g++) {
if (strArray[g][1] == m) {
var l = strArray[g][3];
c.push(l)
}
}
var b = document.createElement(“tr”);
k.appendChild(b);
var d = document.createElement(“td”);
d.setAttribute(“id”, “selectedSubMenu”);
d.style.paddingRight = “0px”;
d.style.paddingLeft = “0px”;
d.style.paddingBottom = “0px”;
d.style.paddingTop = “0px”;
b.appendChild(d);
//product function table
var f = document.createElement(“table”);
f.setAttribute(“id”, “ProdFuncTable”);
f.setAttribute(“cellspacing”, “0”);
f.setAttribute(“cellpadding”, “0”);
f.className = “FuncItem”;
d.appendChild(f);
//product function table body
var a = document.createElement(“tbody”);
a.setAttribute(“id”, “ProdFuncTableBody”);
f.appendChild(a);
//generate function rows
genFuncRow(m, c, a)
}
catch (j) {
showExcpt(“MainMenu”, j)
}
}
/**
* Generate produc function rows
*/
function genFuncRow(s, b, a){
try {
var l= new Array();
var c = new Array();
//get func desc under this product
for (var g = 0; g < nNoOfFuncs; g++) {
var h = strArray[g][5];
var q = strArray[g][12];
if (strArray[i][1] == s) {
l.push(h);
c.push(q);
}
}
//add product row
var o = b.length;
for (var f = 0; f < o; f++) {
 if(inHiddenFuncArray(s,b[f])){continue}
 var p = document.createElement(“tr”);
var n = “funcrow_” + b[f];
p.setAttribute(“id”, n);
var d = document.createElement(“td”);
var r = “funccell_” + b[f];
d.style.paddingRight = “0px”;
d.style.paddingLeft = “14px”;
d.setAttribute(“id”, r);
var k = document.createElement(“a”);
k.setAttribute(“id”, b[f]);
k.href = “#";
if (b[f] == sSelectedFuncId) {
k.className = “SelectedFuncLink”
}
else {
k.className = “FuncLink”
}
k.innerHTML = c[f];
k.onclick = getFuncIdOnClick;
d.appendChild(k);
p.appendChild(d);
a.appendChild(p);
}
}
catch (m) {
showExcpt(“MainMenu”, m)
}
}
/**
* Get product id for product onclick and then generate product menu
*/
function getProdIdOnClick(c){
try {
var i = getEvtTarget(c);
var a = i.id;
if (sSelectedProdId == a) {
var f = document.getElementById(“selectedSubMenu”);
var b = f.style.display;
if (“none” == b) {
f.style.display = “block”
}
else {
f.style.display = “none”
}
}
else {
var g = sSelectedProdId;
sSelectedProdId = a;
var d = i.getAttribute(“pid”);
genProdTable(document.getElementById(d))
}
}
catch (h) {
showExcpt(“MainMenu”, h)
}
}
/**
* Get function id for function onclick and then call funcItemClick()
*/
function getFuncIdOnClick(a){
try {
var g = getEvtTarget(a);
var c = g.id;
sSelectedFuncId = c;
//click function on main menu in the trx, show confirmation msg first
if (!isSEC && (window.SYS_FUNCTION_NAME && window.SYS_FUNCTION_NAME.length > 0)) {
var b = false;
if (SYS_FUNCTION_NAME.indexOf(“View”) != -1) {
b = true
}
if (b || isRptFunc) {
_funcItemClick(sSelectedFuncId)
}
else {
var d = window.confirm(“Data will not be saved if you proceed.");
if (d) {
_funcItemClick(sSelectedFuncId)
}
}
}
else {
//disable fields if it is CSX to CE msg func
if (window.ITEM_ID) {
if (ITEM_ID == “STPDemerge”) {
var h = document.forms.MAINFORM
}
}
_funcItemClick(sSelectedFuncId)
}
}
catch (f) {
showExcpt(“MainMenu”, f)
}
}
/**
* Get function id by function description
*/
function getFuncIdByFuncDesc(b){
try {
for (var c = 0; c < strArray.length; c++) {
if (strArray[c][12] == b && strArray[c][1] == PRODUCT_ID) {
var a = strArray[c][3];
return a
}
}
}
catch (d) {
showExcpt(“MainMenu”, d);
}
}
/**
* Get function description by function id
*/
function getFuncDescByFuncId(b){
try {
for (var c = 0; c < nNoOfFuncs; c++) {
if (strArray[c][3] == b) {
var a = strArray[c][12];
return a;
}
}
}
catch (d) {
showExcpt(“MainMenu”, d)
}
}
/**
* Get function description by function name
*/
function getFuncDescByFuncNm(b){
try {
for (var c = 0; c < nNoOfFuncs; c++) {
if (strArray[c][4] == b) {
var a = strArray[c][12];
return a;
}
}
}
catch (d) {
showExcpt(“MainMenu”, d)
}
};

.dialog {
color: #0064B2;
margin: 0 auto;
margin-bottom: 0.5em; /* spacing under dialog */
margin-left: 12px; /* default,width of left corner */
max-width: 3200px; /* based on image dimensions - not quite consistent with drip styles yet */
min-width: 8em;
position: relative;
z-index: 1;
}
.dialog .content,.dialog .t,.dialog .b,.dialog .b div {
/*background: url(../Images/CE_background.jpg) no-repeat top right;*/
}
.dialog .content {
_overflow-y: hidden;
padding: 0 12px 0 0;
position: relative;
zoom: 1;
}
.dialog .t {
/* top+left vertical slice */
position:absolute;
left:0px;
top:0px;
width:12px;
/* top slice width */
margin-left:-12px;
height:100%;
_height:3200px;
/* arbitrary long height,IE 6 */
background-position:top left;
}
.dialog .b {
position: relative; /* bottom */
width: 100%;
}
.dialog .b,.dialog .b div {
font-size: 1px;
height: 30px; /* height of bottom cap/shade */
}
.dialog .b {
background-position: bottom right;
}
.dialog .b div {
background-position: bottom left;
margin-left: -12px;
position: relative;
width: 12px; /* bottom corner width */
}
.dialog .hd,.dialog .bd,.dialog .ft {
position: relative;
}
.dialog .wrapper {
max-height: 3200px;
height:auto;
/*overflow: auto; *//* note that overflow:auto causes a rather annoying redraw “lag” in Firefox 2,and may degrade performance. Might be worth trying without if you aren’t worried about height/overflow issues. */
position: static; /* extra content protector - preventing vertical overflow (past background) */
}
.dialog h1,.dialog p {
margin: 0; /* margins will blow out backgrounds,leaving whitespace. */
padding: 0.5em 0 0.5em 0;
}
.dialog h1 {
padding-bottom: 0;
}
/* dialog variants - not required for first blue (non-drip) style */
.dialog.type2 .content,.dialog.type2 .t,.dialog.type2 .b,.dialog.type2 .b div {
background-image: url(dialog2-dark-800x1200-alpha-drip.png);
}
/* “drip” variant */
.dialog.drip .b,.dialog.drip .b div {
height: 75px;
}
.dialog.drip {
margin-left: 65px;
}
.dialog.drip .t,.dialog.drip .b div,.dialog.drip .hd,.dialog.drip .bd,.dialog.drip .ft,.dialog.drip .wrapper {
margin-left: -65px;
width: 65px;
}
.dialog.drip .wrapper {
width: auto;
}
.dialog .wrapper .hd,.dialog .wrapper .bd,.dialog .wrapper .ft {
margin-left: 0;
}
.dialog.drip .hd,.dialog.drip .bd,.dialog.drip .ft {
padding: 0 2px 0 12px;
width: auto;
zoom: 1;
}

PART II:
CE WIDGET FRAMEWORK
Introduction to CE Widgets
  Widget Overview and Prerequisites
  The Initial CE Landing Page with widgets
  General Widget Parameter Settings
  Widget Overview and Prerequisites
Widgets
A widget is a small application that can be installed and run within a web page by an end-user. Occupying only a minor portion of a web page, a widget performs a basic functionality. Widgets often take the form of on-screen programs such as calculators and event countdowns.
In CE Version 3.0 and higher, 12 types of widgets are supported. These standard (native) widgets are:
  Calculator
  Calendar Events
  Criteria Search
  Dashboard
  Exchange Rate
  Main Menu
  Notice
  Quick Access
  Recent Functions
  Summary
  Upload Message
  Welcome
  Statistics
   NOTE: The Notice widget is formerly called Notification widget in versions prior to CE Version 3.2.0.
 With this Widget functionality in CE:
  The consultant or developer can:
  import a Widget list into the CE application
  design the look and feel of the CE application with widgets
  The end-user can customize the tabs and widgets of the CE application. The specific attributes of a widget can be modified as well.
  Security FAP and DAP checks are inherited from the current CE entitlements.
  A project team can build its own special widgets and plug it into this framework.
   NOTE: CSWidgets refers to the widget standard of China Systems.
  The CSWidgets widget standard supports most of the features in JSR168 and JSR286. If it is required to show the CE widgets in the bank’s portlet server, major services for the bank’s portlet server can be provided. Moreover, the CSWidgets standard matches the JSR168 and JSR286 portlet standards.
        Figure 9. 1 Example: CE Design Layout with Widgets
Prerequisites
To support widgets on the CE landing page, including the Personalize link that is used for customizing the tabs and widgets, modify the following file:
[PARAMETER DRIVE]\CE_SYS\SYST\sys_screens.xml
 Change the TrxMainMenu setting:     From     <SCREEN> <ALIAS>TrxMainMenu</ALIAS> <DESC>Trx main menu</DESC> <JSPFILE>../screen/SYS_main_menu.jsp</JSPFILE> <TMPLFILE>../Templates/SYS_Template.jsp</TMPLFILE> </SCREEN>   To   <SCREEN> <ALIAS>TrxMainMenu</ALIAS> <DESC>Trx main menu</DESC> <JSPFILE>../screen/widgetMain.jsp</JSPFILE> <TMPLFILE>../Templates/WGT_Template.jsp</TMPLFILE> </SCREEN>        Add this setting:     <SCREEN> <ALIAS>CustomizeWidget</ALIAS> <DESC>Customize Widget</DESC> <JSPFILE>../screen/widgetCust.jsp</JSPFILE> <TMPLFILE>../Templates/WGT_Template.jsp</TMPLFILE> </SCREEN>    After making these modifications, restart the application server.
The Initial CE Landing Page with Widgets
In CE versions that utilize the widget functionality, the browser provides default screen elements. This includes standard or native widgets.
 NOTE: A function (e.g., Add Personalize) may be added in the security module that is used to define available widgets and assign default widgets to be used based on bank and regional country code. Refer to the CE Security and System Maintenance Functions documentation for more information on this function.
        Figure 9. 2 Initial CE Widget Landing Page
 Screen Elements
  Initial access of the CE browser provides the following default screen elements:
   Header section
  Home tab
  Widgets
  Footer section
  Header Section
Aside from the China Systems logo, the header section of the browser shows the following links.
       Figure 9. 3 Header Section
   Link  Description       (Current User)  Clicking on the link that stands for the logged-on user displays a window through which the user password and e-mail can be changed. Refer to Chapter Three: Change User Profile discussion for instructions on changing the password and the e-mail of the logged-on user.          (Languages)  Click on the relevant icon to switch to the corresponding language it represents. NOTE: The languages available are based on multi-language settings. The relevant flag images are added in the following folder – [CEWeb.war folder]\Images\cou – and their corresponding methods added in the BankBanner.lbi file contained in this path: [CEWeb.war folder]\include Refer to the CE Multi-language manual for more details on multi-language settings.        Personalize  This is used for customizing the tabs and widgets to be displayed on the CE browser. NOTE: This link is discussed in detail in the widget sections of this document.        Help  This link is currently not used.        Sign Out  This is used for logging out of the system.    Home Tab
On first accessing the CE browser, a default tab is provided: Home. The Home tab contains two widgets: Main Menu and Welcome.
       Figure 9. 4 Default Tab: Home
Other tabs, as well as widgets, can be added to the system as required.
 NOTE: For details on adding tabs, refer to the following discussion in this chapter:
  Basic CE Widget Operations > Adding Tabs on the Landing Page
 Widgets
The default tab of the CE system, Home, contains these widgets: Main Menu and Welcome.
Figure 9. 5 Default Widgets: Main Menu and Welcome
Other widgets, as well as tabs, can be added to the system as required.
 NOTE: For details on adding widgets, refer to the following discussion in this chapter: Basic CE Widget Operations > Displaying Widgets.
 Footer Section
The footer section displays the copyright information of the CE system, as well as links that point to information about China Systems.
       Figure 9. 6 Footer Section
 Basic CE Widget Operations
  With the initial and default widget settings in CE, the end-user can perform the following on the CE landing page:
   Display specific widgets
  Remove specific widgets
  Add tabs
   These are configured through the Personalize page of the system.
  NOTE: The Personalize page is also referred to as the Page Builder.
  Displaying Widgets
  The CE landing page may contain multiple tabs. The layout of a tab can support:
   A maximum of three columns; and
  Each column can contain as many widget instances as required.
By default, the system provides the Home tab with the Main Menu and Welcome widget instances.
   NOTE: Widgets of the same type are called instances of that widget.
  To add a widget on the relevant tab:
    Do the following . . .       1. Log on the CE system as an Operator user. The CE landing page is displayed.            2. Click on the Personalize link.          3. The Personalize page is displayed. On the left section is the Product Services panel. This lists all the available widgets. The right section displays the available tabs and their corresponding widget instances. Click on the tab to which the widget instance is to be added. Relevant sections are allocated for cross-column widgets. EXAMPLE: The Main Menu and Welcome widgets have been added to the Home tab. NOTE: Refer to the Adjusting Widget Layouts discussion in this chapter for more details on cross-column widgets.          NOTE: The types of widgets that are made available on the Product Services depend on the role of the logged-on user. A widget type is assigned to specific user roles.          4. From the Product Services panel, click and drag the widget to the right section and towards the relevant tab. EXAMPLE: The Notification widget is to be added to the Home tab.          5. An instance of this widget is now added to the tab. Click on the Save Changes button. NOTE: The Save and Discard links can be used to save and discard changes or actions made.          6. A confirmation message is displayed. Click on the Done button.          NOTE: Depending on the setting configured for it, a widget may or may not be utilized on the same tab multiple times. (For settings, refer to the following discussion in this chapter: General Widget Parameter Settings > Widget Profile Settings > Procedure). A disabled widget name on the Product Services panel indicates that it can no longer be added to the current tab (through drag-and-drop). As long as the widget name is enabled, then it can be added multiple times to the current tab: multiple instances of this widget can be displayed and utilized on that tab. EXAMPLE: Given that: 1) There are two tabs: Home and Test; 2) The Welcome widget has been defined to be utilized only once; 3) The Main Menu widget has been defined to be utilized multiple times; and 4) The Home tab already contains a Main Menu widget instance. Do the following: Access the Home tab. The tab already contains an instance of the Main Menu widget. On the Product Services panel, the Main Menu widget name remains enabled. This indicates that another or more instances of the Main Menu widget can be added to the tab. Drag and drop a Welcome widget instance to the Home tab. The Welcome widget name on the Product Services panel becomes disabled. This indicates that the system cannot allow another instance of the Welcome widget to be utilized on the Home tab. Access the Test tab. The Welcome widget instance on the Product Services panel becomes enabled. Drag and drop a Welcome widget instance to the Test tab. The Welcome widget name on the Product Services panel becomes disabled. This indicates that the system cannot allow another instance of the Welcome widget to be utilized on the Test tab. Drag and drop two instances of the Main Menu widget to the Test tab. The widget name remains enabled on the Product Services panel.  Tabs: Home and Test Home tab Test tab:         NOTE: The arrangement of widgets can be changed by dragging and dropping the widgets to the relevant positions.          7. The system returns to the landing page. The added widget instance is shown on the relevant tab.       Adjusting Widget Layouts
  The CE system supports a maximum of 4 widget columns.
  It also provides the feature to set the width of a widget to occupy 2 columns on the screen, while maintaining the set column layout for other widgets. This allows widgets that have more details and be more readable and accessible.
  If a widget is set to occupy two columns, it is called a Cross Column Widget.
  To enable cross column widgets, the following items must be configured:
   widget.xml of the relevant widget.
  TWO_COLUMNS_WIDGET system parameter
  Widget JSP and JS files
    NOTE: For lower CE versions, a maximum of 3 widget columns is supported.
    Widget.xml File
To enable cross column widgets, the acrossColumn attribute must be modified or added to the corresponding widget.xml file of the relevant widget.
 NOTE: Once the value of the acrossColumn attribute is set to Y and the widget is added to the cross column section, it may not be reverted back to a normal widget until the acrossColumn attribute is set to N and the application server is restarted.
  Example:
  <iw:itemSet id="attributes”>
  <iw:item id="acrossColumn” alias="acrossColumn” lang=”” readOnly="false” value="Y”/>
  </iw:itemSet>
 TWO_COLUMNS_WIDGET System Parameter
This parameter is used to define whether the width of a widget is to be automatically adjusted or to be retained to its default setting.
If the value of this parameter is set to TRUE, the system automatically adjusts the width of each column to occupy 50% of the browser page width. This applies if the widgets are set to occupy only two columns on the browser page.
If the value of this parameter is set to FALSE, the width of each column remains at 33% of the browser page width, regardless if the defined layout is two or three columns.
Layout.jsp
The layout.jsp file is used to define the columns on the landing page where widgets are to be arranged.
This is also used to define the location of cross column section. Different sets of codes are provided to display the cross column section either on the left side or right side of the page.
 NOTE: Refer to the Setting Widget Columns discussion in Chapter 23 for more information on widget column settings.
 To display the cross column section on the right side of the page for 3 column widget setting, the layout.jsp file must have the following contents:
   <%@ taglib uri=”/LFTAGS” prefix="widget” %> <%@ taglib uri = “/MLGTAG” prefix = “MLG”%> <widget:resource type="layout” path="column3.css”/> <% // //CEV2-04-01-12 harry.wang %> <div id="layoutContainers” class="csLayoutContainers”> <div id="com_cs_widgets_layout_R1C3” class="component-container layoutCol csLayoutColumn3 oneColumn”> <widget:wrappers cellId="com_cs_widgets_layout_R1C3”/> </div> <div class="line”> <div id="com_cs_widgets_layout_R1C4” class="component-container layoutCol4 csLayoutColumn4 twoColumn”> <div id="call-word” align="center” style="font-size:30px;color:gray;position:relative;">Please drag the cross - column widget to here. </div> <widget:wrappers cellId="com_cs_widgets_layout_R1C4”/> </div> <div class="line2”> <div id="com_cs_widgets_layout_R1C1” class="component-container layoutCol csLayoutColumn1 oneColumn”> <widget:wrappers cellId="com_cs_widgets_layout_R1C1”/> </div> <div id="com_cs_widgets_layout_R1C2” class="component-container layoutColM csLayoutColumn2 oneColumn”> <widget:wrappers cellId="com_cs_widgets_layout_R1C2”/> </div> </div> </div> </div> <%@ page import="com.cs.core.cache.CacheSYSHelper”%> <%@ page import="com.cs.core.utility.StringUtil”%> <%String twoColumnsWidget = CacheSYSHelper.getSysParam(“TWO_COLUMNS_WIDGET”);  Column3.css
The column3.css file contains Cascading Style Sheets (CSS) codes that are used to define the format and layout of the html elements that are defined in the layout.jsp file.
To enable cross column widgets, this file must have the following contents:
   .widgetMain { background: none repeat scroll 0 0 #FFFFFF; border: 0 none; padding: 10px 0 0; min-height: 600px; position: relative; height:auto !important; display: inline-block; width:100%; } .widgetMain .csLayoutContainers{ overflow: visible; padding: 0; display: inline-block; width: 100%; } .widgetMain .csLayoutContainers .component-container { float: left; display: inline; position: relative; box-sizing:border-box; } .widgetMain .csLayoutContainers .component-container.csLayoutColumn1, .component-container.csLayoutColumn4{ padding-left: 5px; } /*.widgetMain .csLayoutContainers .layoutCol, .widgetMain .csLayoutContainers .layoutColM { width: 33%; min-height: 600px; height:auto ; }*/ #loading.tb.lt{ display: none; } #loading .msgp .bar .rate.ltr{ width: 33%; } .widgetMain .csLayoutContainers .component-container.csLayoutColumn1, .component-container.csLayoutColumn2{ width: 50%; min-height: 600px; height:auto; } .widgetMain .csLayoutContainers .component-container.csLayoutColumn3{ width: 33%; min-height: 600px; height:auto; } .widgetMain .csLayoutContainers .layoutCol4 { width: 100%; min-height: 120px; height:auto; border:1px dashed #C0C0C0; } .line{ float:left; display: inline; width:66%; } .line2{ float:left; display:block; width:100%; }    Personalize.js

 The CSWidget.js file contains JavaScript codes that handle the behavior of widgets.
  To enable cross column widgets, the following items must be added to the Constants block:
   layoutCols1:".twoColumn”
  layoutCols2:".oneColumn”
   Example:
    Constants:{ navTabRoot:".widgetNavTabs”, layoutRoot:".widgetMain”, layoutBody:".csLayoutContainers”, layoutCols:".component-container”, //CEV2-04-01-12 harry.wang s layoutCols1:".twoColumn”, layoutCols2:".oneColumn”, //CEV2-04-01-12 harry.wang e widgetRoot:".component-control”, widgetHead:".decoration-titlebar”, widgetBody:".csWidgetBody”, widgetFoot:".decoration-toolbar”, actMenuIcon:".cs-mode-menu”, placeholder:“widget-placeholder”, widgetsPool:".widgetsPool”, settingBar:".settingBar”, initMode:“view”, personalize:false, personalizeBtn:".personalizeBtn”, TabSource:"../widgets/framework/scripts/Tabs.js”, ActionMenuSource:"../widgets/framework/scripts/WidgetActionMenu.js”, lang:null, SUPPORTED_IE:[“6.0”,“7.0”,“8.0”,“9.0”,“10.0”] } } });       Do the following . . .       Configuring the widget.xml File 1. Open the corresponding widget.xml file of the widget to be set as a cross-column. This file is located in the [Parameter Drive]:\CE_SYS\WIDGETS\[widget name] folder.            2. Set the value of the acrossColumn attribute to Y. Once done, save the changes made to the file.          Modifying the TWO_COLUMNS_WIDGET System Parameter 3. Log on to the CE Utility as a super administrator user.          4. Run the System Parameters function from the Parameter Manage function group.          5. Select the TWO_COLUMNS_WIDGET parameter, and click on the Edit button on the toolbar.          6. The Modify Parameter Config window is displayed. Set the Parameter Value to TRUE. Once done, click on the Save button.          XML GENERATION: Log on to the CE Utility as an operator user.          Run the XML Generator function and select System Parameter. Mark the Security System Parameter option.          The XML file for system parameters is generated in this folder: [Parameter Drive]:\CE_SYS\SYST\sys_para.xml          Modifying JSP and JS Files 7. Open the layout.jsp file. This file is located in the CEWeb.war:\widgets\framework\layouts\column3 folder.          8. Specify the required information. Once done, save the changes made to the file. NOTE: Refer to Chapter 9: Layout.jsp for the required contents of the layout.jsp file.          9. Open the column3.css file. This file is located in the CEWeb.war:\widgets\framework\layouts\column3 folder.          10. Specify the required details. Once done, save the changes made to the file. NOTE: Refer to Chapter 9: Column3.css for the required contents of the column3.css file.          11. Open the Personalize.js file. This file is located in the CEWeb.war:\widgets\framework\personalize folder.          12. Specify the required details. Once done, save the changes made to the file. NOTE: Refer to Chapter 9: Personalize.js for the required contents of the Personalize.js file.          13. Open the CSWidget.js file. This file is located in the CEWeb.war:\widgets\framework\scripts folder.          14. Specify the required details. Once done, save the changes made to the file. NOTE: Refer to Chapter 9: CSWidget.js for the required contents of the CSWidget.js file.          Application Server Restart After configuring all required parameters, the application server must be restarted.          Adjusting Widget Layouts 1. Log on the CE system as an Operator user. The CE landing page is displayed.          2. Click on the Personalize link that is located on the top right corner of the page.          3. The Personalize page is displayed. On the left section is the Product Services panel. This lists all the available widgets. The right section displays the available tabs and their corresponding widget instances. Click on the tab to which the widget instance is to be added. The cross column section is displayed. NOTE: The position of the cross column section is determined based on the settings defined in the layout.jsp file. Refer to Chapter 9: Layout.jsp.          4. From the Product Services panel, click and drag the widget to the right section and towards the cross column section of the relevant tab. EXAMPLE: The Dashboard widget is to be added to the Home tab, and is set as a cross column widget.          5. An instance of this widget is now added to the tab. Click on the Save Changes button. NOTE: The Save and Discard links can be used to save and discard changes or actions made.          6. A confirmation message is displayed. Click on the Done button.          NOTE: The arrangement of widgets can be changed by dragging and dropping the widgets to the relevant positions.          7. The system returns to the landing page. The added widget instance is shown on the relevant tab.          NOTE: Use the Column Number field to specify the number of widget columns that are to be used. Refer to the Setting Widget Columns discussion in Chapter 23 for more details on widget columns.       Removing Widgets
  To remove a widget from the relevant tab on the landing page:
    Do the following . . .       1. Log on to the CE system as an Operator user. The CE landing page is displayed.            2. Click on the Personalize link.          3. The Personalize page is displayed. On the left section is the Product Services panel. This lists all the available widget (or widget instances). The right section displays the available tabs and their corresponding widget instances. Click on the tab that contains the widget instance to be removed. EXAMPLE: The Main Menu, Welcome, and Quick Access widgets have been added to the Home tab.          4. Each widget instance is provided with a menu.          Open this menu and click on the Remove option to delete the widget instance. EXAMPLE: The Quick Access widget is to be removed from the Home tab.          5. The widget instance has now been deleted. Click on the Save Changes button. NOTE: The Save and Discard links can be used to save and discard changes or actions made.          6. A confirmation message is displayed. Click on the Done button.          7. The system returns to the landing page. The deleted widget instance is no longer shown on the relevant tab.       Adding Tabs on the Landing Page
  A tab may contain several widgets. It may take some time, however, to load the page if a tab contains too many widgets. Multiple tabs, each containing a set of widgets, enable the system to load all the screen elements more efficiently.
  The system provides a default tab: Home. To add a tab on the landing page:
    Do the following . . .       1. Log on the CE system as an Operator user. The CE landing page is displayed.            2. Click on the Personalize link.          3. The Personalize page is displayed. On the left section is the Product Services panel. This lists all the available widgets. The right section displays the available tabs and their corresponding widget instances. EXAMPLE: The available and current tab is the Home tab.          4. Click on the Add New Tab button.          NOTE: The Show Grid button is used for displaying the grid on the screen in order to better view the alignment of the widgets.          5. A new tab is shown. Specify the name of this new tab in the field provided.          6. The specified name is reflected on the actual tab. Click on the Save Changes button. NOTE: The Save and Discard links can be used to save and discard changes or actions made.          A tab is added, labeled with the name previously specified. Arrange the widgets to be included in each tab and save the changes made. NOTE: For adding a widget to a new tab, refer to this previous discussion: Displaying Widgets.          7. A confirmation message is displayed. Click on the Done button.          8. The system returns to the landing page.          The new tab is now added to the landing page. Click on the name of the new tab to access this tab.          The new tab’s page is then displayed.          NOTE: To rename a tab, access it on the Personalize page. Specify a new name in the Name field provided and save the setting.          To delete a tab, access it on the Personalize page. Either click on the X symbol or click on the Close button. Save the setting.          To arrange the order of tabs, go to the Personalize page. Drag the tab to the required position and save the setting.          In case the tabs are not properly aligned horizontally, modify the following file: CEWeb.war\theme\default\widgets\tabs.css. Comment out the display code.      General Widget Parameter Settings
All widget types require a profile definition. This profile definition can also be used for creating another widget of the same primary attributes.
With some widgets, additional or advanced settings are required.
 NOTE: The specific settings that apply to a particular widget type are discussed in the chapter dedicated to that widget.
  Widget Profile Settings
  The Widget profile is defined through the Widget Maintain function.
  Configuration
  Define the following details in the Widget Profile window.
        Figure 9. 7 Widget Profile Window
   Field  Field Description       Widget Name  Specify the unique key of the widget. In configuring any of the 12 basic CE widgets, the following exact names must be followed: Calculator CalendarEvents CriteriaSearch Dashboard ExchangeRate MainMenu Notification QuickAccess RecentFunction Summary UploadMessage WelcomeBox NOTE: A widget profile that is based on any of the 12 CE standard widgets can be created. This functionality is done through the Extend Definition File option. Refer to the Widget Definition File Extension discussion in this chapter for more details.          Description  Provide the description of the widget. This becomes the default name of the widget in the Frame Work list section in the Widget Setting tab of the Widget Maintain function window.        Widget Type  This is currently not used. Nonetheless, make sure that the Global option is selected.        Version  Specify the version of the widget. This is used for information and tracking purposes in case the widget is updated in the future.        System Role  Assign the user role for the widget: select the kinds of users to which the widget is to be made available. The user roles are: Super Officer Bank Administrator Bank Operator Customer Administrator Customer Operator At least one user role must be selected. Otherwise, it cannot be used by any user once this setting is synchronized with the database. Upon synchronization (through the Synchronize to DB button), the widget details defined here are going to override the original settings in the database. NOTE: These roles are stored in the SEC_WIDGET_RIGHTS table. The values are 0, for Super Officer; 1 for Customer Administrator; 2, for Customer Operator; 3 for Bank Administrator; and 4, for Bank Operator.        Status  This indicates whether or not the widget can be used. Select the Active option. NOTE: The Inactive option is currently not used.     Procedure
    To configure the Welcome widget…       1. Run the Widget Maintain function from the Transaction Function group.            2. The Widget Maintain window is displayed. The window shows the following tabs: Widget Profile Widget Setting From the Widget Profile tab, click on the Add button on the toolbar.          NOTE: The Widget Profile tab also provides the following buttons: Synchronize to DB Import Export as SQL          Synchronize to DB button is used for inserting the widget profiles to the database. The new widget settings defined in this function override the original data in the database. This is used in the testing environment only.          The Import button is used for importing a default XML configuration file for some widget profiles. Note that: Only the profile details are imported; and The XML file may contain, or may be edited to contain, multiple widget profiles through the addition of <widget> nodes. Duplicate widget instances cannot be imported.          The Export as SQL button is used to generate and export the SQL commands for creating these widget profiles to an SQL file. The SQL file can be run in the production environment in order to import the widget data saved in the testing database.          3. The Widget Profile window is displayed. Specify the required details for the new widget profile and click on the Save button.          4. The newly created widget profile is displayed in the grid.          5. Click on the Synchronize to DB button in order to update the database with the newly defined widget settings. NOTE: Once created, the widget profile is inserted into the CEMETA.ECD_WIDGET_PROFILE table. When the Synchronize to DB button is clicked, the profile is inserted into the CEUSER.SEC_WIDGET and CEUSER.SEC_WIDGET_RIGHTS tables.          6. Access the Widget Setting tab. This contains two sub-tabs: Generate Setting and Advance Setting.          7. From the Frame Work list in the Generate Setting tab, double-click on the newly created widget. Alternatively, select the widget and click on the Edit button on the toolbar.          8. A configuration window is displayed. To import predefined settings for the widget profile, click on the browse button for Import Definition File option. NOTE: The Extend Definition File option is used for applying the settings of an existing widget profile to create a new widget profile (i.e., extension). Refer to this section: Widget Definition File Extension          9. The Open dialog box is displayed. Browse for the widget.xml file – i.e., the widget definition file –from the relevant directory. NOTE: The widget.xml can be placed in any directory. It can also be modified directly and later imported through this same process. EXAMPLE: AppSrv01\CE_SYS\WIDGETS\WelcomeBox\widget.xml          10. The content of the imported file is shown on the configuration window. Check or modify the settings as required.          NOTE: To define whether or not multiple instances of the widget can be added to the same tab on the CE browser, set the allowInstanceContent attribute to either: false: Only one instance of the widget can be dragged and dropped to the same tab. true: Multiple instances of the widget can be dragged and dropped to the same tab.          When done with the settings, click on the Save button and close the window.          11. The system returns to the function window, which now shows the content of the imported definition file.          XML GENERATION: Run the XML Generator function and select the Widget Maintain parameter type. Make sure to mark the created widget profile in the XML Generator – Widget Maintain window that is displayed.          The XML file for the new widget profile is generated: [PARAMETER DRIVE]\CE_SYS\WIDGETS\[WIDGET NAME]\widget.xml This is the updated version of the definition file that has been used for the widget profile: widget.xml. The settings only apply to this specific widget profile. EXAMPLE: [PARAMETER DRIVE]\CE_SYS\WIDGETS\WelcomeBox\widget.xml       NOTE: The other (non-profile) settings that are specific to a particular widget type are discussed in the chapter dedicated to that widget.
  Widget Definition File Extension
  Any one of the 12 standard CE widgets can be used to create a new widget profile that is to have the same attributes.
  EXAMPLE:
  The Summary widget is used for viewing and accessing one type of records only (via catalog). The widget must be configured on Edit mode in order to display records from other particular catalogs.
  For easier and faster access to other types of records, additional Summary widgets, using the attributes of the standard Summary widget, can be created.
    Do the following . . .       1. Run the Widget Maintain function from the Transaction Function group.            2. The Widget Maintain window is displayed. The window shows the following tabs: Widget Profile Widget Setting          3. Through the Widget Profile tab, create a new widget profile. The name must be different from any of the 12 standard CE widgets. EXAMPLE: Widget Name: SummaryEXLC Description: Summary for Export LC NOTE: Widget profile configuration is detailed in this section: General Widget Parameter Settings > Widget Profile Settings          4. The newly created widget profile is displayed in the grid.          5. Click on the Synchronize to DB button in order to update the database with the newly defined widget settings.          6. Access the Widget Setting tab. This contains two sub-tabs: Generate Setting and Advance Setting.          7. From the Frame Work list in the Generate Setting tab, double-click on the newly created widget. Alternatively, select the widget and click on the Edit button on the toolbar.          8. A configuration window is displayed. Mark the Extend Definition File option. From the accompanying dropdown list that is then enabled, select the standard widget which attributes are to be applied to the new widget. EXAMPLE: Extend Definition File: Summary NOTE: The Import Definition File option is used for importing the settings of a specific widget XML configuration file. Refer to: Widget Profile Settings          9. The settings defined for this standard widget are shown on the configuration window.          10. Change the description.          Make sure that the idescriptor tag is set to the defined description of the new widget. EXAMPLE: New widget description: Summary for Export LC          11. When done with the modifications, click on the Save button and close the window.          12. The system returns to the function window, which now shows the updated content of the imported definition file.          XML GENERATION: WIDGET PROFILE Run the XML Generator function and select the Widget Maintain parameter type. Make sure to mark the created widget profile in the XML Generator – Widget Maintain window that is displayed.          The XML file for the new widget profile is generated: [PARAMETER DRIVE]\CE_SYS\WIDGETS\[WIDGET NAME]\widget.xml This is the updated version of the definition file that has been used for the widget profile: widget.xml. The settings only apply to this specific widget profile. EXAMPLE: [PARAMETER DRIVE]\CE_SYS\WIDGETS\SummaryEXLC\widget.xml          13. Proceed with the other parameter settings required of the new widget. EXAMPLE: For the new SummaryEXLC widget, additional settings are required in the Advance Setting sub-tab of the Widget Setting tab. NOTE: Refer to the settings of the standard widget. There are separate chapters for each widget type. In this example, the standard widget is the Summary widget. Refer to Chapter Nineteen.          XML GENERATION: ADVANCED WIDGET SETTINGS Run the XML Generator function and select the Widget Maintain parameter type. Make sure to mark the widget profile in the XML Generator – Widget Maintain window that is displayed.          The XML files are generated on this path: [PARAMETER DRIVE]\CE_SYS\WIDGETS\[WIDGET NAME] EXAMPLE: [PARAMETER DRIVE]\CE_SYS\WIDGETS\SummaryEXLC          The following file is also updated: [PARAMETER DRIVE]\CE_SYS\WIDGETS\framework\extension-widgets.xml. NOTE: Make sure to clear the browser history and restart the server.          14. On the CE browser, access the Personalize page.          15. The new widget profile, created based on an existing profile (i.e., extension), is now included in the Product Services list. Use or configure the new widget accordingly.          Use or configure the new widget accordingly. NOTE: The CSS file to be applied to the widget is copied in this directory: CEWeb.war\CE_SYS\WIDGETS\[WIDGET NAME].       Other Widget Settings
 Widget Action Popup Setting
The WIDGET_ACTION_POPUP security parameter is used to control whether the system pops up a new window when a widget hyperlink or button is clicked. The following is an example of how the system displays the relevant screen when this this parameter is set to TRUE.
EXAMPLE:
In the Dashboard widget, click on the View Import LC link. The View Import LC screen is displayed on a popup window:
  In the Criteria Search widget, select the Import Letters of Credit – Authorise Transaction option from the Search For dropdown field and click on the Search button. The Authorise Transaction screen is displayed on a popup window:
  RTL Settings
The RTL security parameter is used to change how widgets, transaction functions, and error messages are displayed on the CE page: certain elements are re-arranged from right to left.
For widgets –
  The hyperlinks follow this order – Sign Out, Help, Personalize, [User Name] – instead of: [User Name], Personalize, Help, and Sign Out.
  The Title and Description elements, when personalizing a widget, are right-aligned.
  The functions from these widgets are right-aligned: Main Menu and its Search tool, Quick Access, and Recent Functions.
  The descriptions are displayed on the right: Upload Message, Welcome, Criteria Search,
  Calendar Events: The weekends and weekdays are displayed from right to left.
  The elements are reversed: Exchange Rate (rates first, then the currencies), Summary, Notice.
  For transaction functions:
  The tabs and buttons are displayed in reversed order.
  The field descriptions are displayed on the right.
  For error messages:
 The error messages are right-aligned.  To enable this right-to-left style for widgets:
   Do the following . . .       1. As a Super Administrator user, run the System Parameters function from the Parameter Manage function group of the CE Utility.            2. Set the RTL system parameter value to: dir=’rtl’.          3. As an Operator user, run the XML Generator function from the Maintenance function group.          4. In the Web Server tab, double-click on System Parameter and select the following options in the window that is displayed: Security System Parameter System Session Data Click on the Save button.          5. Open the widget JS file found in this path: [WEB SERVER DRIVE]\ widgets\framework\scripts\CSWidget.js Add the codes in red font.
