Specific Widget Settings
Some widget types require:
  Advanced settings in the Widget Maintain function in the CE Utility
  Settings in another CE Utility function (e.g., Notification function)
  Prerequisite products and functions (e.g., Notification View and Label products)
  These specific settings that apply only to particular widget types are discussed in their respective chapters.
The Calculator Widget
  Overview
  Parameter Settings
  Browser Settings
  Overview
The Calculator widget is a tool for basic calculation operations.
       Figure 10. 1 The Calculator Widget
 NOTE: For a quick overview on how the Calculator widget works, refer to the following discussion in this chapter:
  Browser Settings > Using the Calculator Widget
 Parameter Settings
The parameter settings for the Calculator widget are configured in the Widget Maintain function.
   Do the following . . .       1. Run the Widget Maintain function from the Transaction Function group.            2. The Widget Maintain window is displayed. The window shows the following tabs: Widget Profile Widget Setting From the Widget Profile tab, click on the Add button on the toolbar.          3. The Widget Profile window is displayed. Specify the required details for the new widget. Make sure that the Widget Name is set to: Calculator. Click on the Save button. NOTE: For details on the other profile settings, refer to: Chapter Nine > General Widget Parameter Settings > Widget Profile Settings          4. The newly created widget profile is displayed in the grid.          5. Click on the Synchronize to DB button in order to update the database with the newly defined widget settings.          6. Access the Widget Setting tab. This contains two sub-tabs: Generate Setting and Advance Setting.          7. From the Frame Work list in the Generate Setting tab, double-click on the newly created widget. Alternatively, select the widget and click on the Edit button on the toolbar.          8. A configuration window is displayed. To import predefined settings for the widget profile, click on the browse button for the Import Definition File option. NOTE: The Extend Definition File option is used for applying the settings of an existing widget profile to create a new widget profile. Refer to this discussion: Chapter Nine > General Widget Parameter Settings > Widget Definition File Extension          9. The Open dialog box is displayed. Browse for the widget.xml file – i.e., the widget definition file –from the relevant directory. NOTE: The widget.xml can be placed in any directory. It can also be modified directly and later imported through this same process. EXAMPLE: AppSrv01\CE_SYS\WIDGETS\Calculator\widget.xml          10. The content of the imported file is shown on the configuration window. Check or modify the settings as required.          NOTE: To define whether or not multiple instances of the widget can be added to the same tab on the CE browser, set the allowInstanceContent attribute to either: false: Only one instance of the widget can be dragged and dropped to the same tab. true: Multiple instances of the widget can be dragged and dropped to the same tab.          When done with the settings, click on the Save button and close the window.          11. The system returns to the function window, which now shows the content of the imported definition file.          XML GENERATION: Run the XML Generator function and select the Widget Maintain parameter type. Make sure to mark the created widget profile in the XML Generator – Widget Maintain window that is displayed.          The XML file for the new widget profile is generated: [PARAMETER DRIVE]\CE_SYS\WIDGETS\Calculator\widget.xml This is the updated version of the definition file that has been used for the widget profile: widget.xml. The settings only apply to this specific widget profile.      Browser Settings
Before using the Calculator widget and modifying its properties:
  Log on the CE system as an Operator user; and
  Add the Calculator widget to the relevant tab as described in Chapter Nine > The Initial CE Landing Page with Widgets > Basic CE Widget Operations > Displaying Widgets.
   Using the Calculator Widget
  To use the Calculator widget:
    Do the following . . .       1. Click on the relevant tab to access the Calculator widget.            2. Use the Calculator widget accordingly.          NOTE: The Calculator widget provides a menu containing the Refresh, Maximize, Minimize, and Help window options.       Changing the Calculator Widget Properties
  Through the Personalize link, the title and description of the Calculator widget can be modified. The title appears on the title bar of the widget window. The description, on the other hand, appears as a tooltip.
    Do the following . . .       1. Click on the Personalize link.            2. The Personalize page is displayed.          3. The Calculator window shows the current title and description of the widget.          NOTE: The Calculator window provides a menu with the Remove, Refresh, Maximize, Minimize, and Help window options.          4. Modify the Calculator title and description, and save the settings.          5. Click on the Save Changes button. NOTE: The Save and Discard links can be used to save and discard changes or actions made.          6. A confirmation message is displayed. Click on the Done button.          7. The system returns to the landing page.          The Calculator widget reflects the new title and description.      The Calendar Events Widget
  Overview
  Parameter SEttings
  Browser Settings
  Overview
The Calendar Events widget, aside from showing basic calendar information, provides the following functionalities:
  Weekends and holidays are highlighted for easy identification.
  Dates with events are appropriately marked with flags.
  The types of events to be utilized by the widget can be defined.
  Notes can be recorded for specific dates.
  Functions can be started – and the relevant record viewed or processed – through the given events. These events pertain to specific transaction dates (e.g., LC expiry dates).
  The availability of events to the end-user is FAP-controlled: the user must have rights to the related function in order to view and access the events.
       Figure 11. 1 The Calendar Events Widget
 NOTE: For a quick overview on how the Calendar Events widget works, refer to the following discussion in this chapter:
  Browser Settings > Using the Calendar Events Widget
 Parameter Settings
The main parameter settings for the Calendar Events widget are configured in the Widget Maintain function. This includes widget profile and advanced settings.
Additional parameter settings are required: sub-catalogs.
 Widget Profile Settings
  To configure the profile settings for the Calendar Events widget:
    Do the following . . .       1. Run the Widget Maintain function from the Transaction Function group.            2. The Widget Maintain window is displayed. The window shows the following tabs: Widget Profile Widget Setting From the Widget Profile tab, click on the Add button on the toolbar.          3. The Widget Profile window is displayed. Specify the required details for the new widget. Make sure that the Widget Name is set to: CalendarEvents. Click on the Save button. NOTE: For details on the other profile settings, refer to: Chapter Nine > General Widget Parameter Settings > Widget Profile Settings          4. The newly created widget profile is displayed in the grid.          5. Click on the Synchronize to DB button in order to update the database with the newly defined widget settings.          6. Access the Widget Setting tab. This contains two sub-tabs: Generate Setting and Advance Setting.          7. From the Frame Work list in the Generate Setting tab, double-click on the newly created widget. Alternatively, select the widget and click on the Edit button on the toolbar.          8. A configuration window is displayed. To import predefined settings for the widget profile, click on the browse button for the Import Definition File option. NOTE: The Extend Definition File option is used for applying the settings of an existing widget profile to create a new widget profile. Refer to this discussion: Chapter Nine > General Widget Parameter Settings > Widget Definition File Extension          9. The Open dialog box is displayed. Browse for the widget.xml file – i.e., the widget definition file –from the relevant directory. NOTE: The widget.xml can be placed in any directory. It can also be modified directly and later imported through this same process. EXAMPLE: AppSrv01\CE_SYS\WIDGETS\CalendarEvents\widget.xml          10. The content of the imported file is shown on the configuration window. Check or modify the settings as required.          NOTE: To define whether or not multiple instances of the widget can be added to the same tab on the CE browser, set the allowInstanceContent attribute to either: false: Only one instance of the widget can be dragged and dropped to the same tab. true: Multiple instances of the widget can be dragged and dropped to the same tab.          When done with the settings, click on the Save button and close the window.          11. The system returns to the function window, which now shows the content of the imported definition file.          XML GENERATION: WIDGET PROFILE Run the XML Generator function and select the Widget Maintain parameter type. Make sure to mark the created widget profile in the XML Generator – Widget Maintain window that is displayed.          The CALENDAR_EVENTS.xml and widget.xml files for the new widget profile are generated on the following path: [PARAMETER DRIVE]\CE_SYS\WIDGETS\ CalendarEvents This is the updated version of the definition file that has been used for the widget profile: widget.xml. The settings only apply to this specific widget profile.       Advanced Widget Settings
  The advanced settings for the Calendar Events widget involve:
   Configuring the sub-catalogs to be utilized by this widget
  Associating the sub-catalogs to the types of events to be used by this widget
   Sub-Catalog Settings
  The events in the Calendar Events widget are made accessible through the sub-catalogs of the related transaction function.
  For each type of event to be utilized by the Calendar Events widget, two sub-catalogs are required:
   A sub-catalog for searching and displaying records that match a specific date event (e.g., LC maturity date). These records are accessed through the relevant date in the Calendar Events widget.
  A sub-catalog for searching the number of records for this (date) event
To create a sub-catalog for an event type:
     Do the following . . .       1. Run Transaction Function from the Transaction Function group.            2. Access the module, event, and function for which the sub-catalog is to be defined. EXAMPLE: Module: Import Letters of Credit Event: System Maintenance Function: IMLC View Import LC          3. Access the Catalog component of the function. Two tabs are provided: Main Catalog and Sub Catalog. NOTE: The function must already have a defined main catalog.          4. Access the Sub Catalog tab.          NOTE: If the event requires multiple tables: The Catalog parameter must be manually defined in [PARAMETER DRIVE]\CE_SYS\WIDGETS\CalendarEvents\calendar.xml. Specify the multi-table inquiry parameter settings (catalog settings, multiple tables) accordingly. An adapter must be defined for the sub-catalog (through the Adapter flag and dropdown list).          Sub-Catalog for Displaying and Processing the Date Event Records From the Sub Catalog tab, click on the Add button on the toolbar to add a sub-catalog.          Define the sub-catalog details.          Define the criteria for the sub-catalog.          EXAMPLE: Date of IMLC Expiring LCs: This sub-catalog is used for searching LC records that expire on a specific date. EXPIRY_DT: The value is retrieved from the database.          The first Value or FROM_DATE: The value pertains to the first date on the Calendar page that is displayed.                    The second Value or TO_DATE: The value pertains to the last date on the Calendar page that is displayed.                    Sub-Catalog for the Number of Event Records From the Sub Catalog tab, click on the Add button on the toolbar to add a sub-catalog.          Define the sub-catalog details.          Define the criteria for the sub-catalog.          EXAMPLE: Number of IMLC Expiring LCs: This sub-catalog is used for determining the number of LC records that expire on a specific date. EXPIRY_DT: The value is retrieved from the database.          The first Value or CURR_DATE: The value pertains to the current date on which the transaction is to be performed. The alias name must be set to CURR_DATE. (The value is the same as that of the second Value or CURR_DATE.)                    The second Value or CURR_DATE: The value pertains to the current date on which the transaction is to be performed. The alias name must be set to CURR_DATE. (The value is the same as that of the first Value or CURR_DATE.)                    Other Sub-Catalogs Add as many sub-catalogs as required. EXAMPLE: Sub-catalogs defined for IMLC View Import LC: Number of IMLC Maturing LCs Date of IMLC Maturing LCs Number of IMLC Expiring LCs Date of IMLC Expiring LCs          XML GENERATION: Run the XML Generator function and generate the relevant XML files.       Event Settings
  Once the relevant sub-catalogs have been defined, these must then be associated to the event types of the Calendar Events widget.
  These event types are configured as advanced settings in the Widget Maintain function.
  Configuration
  Associating event types and sub-catalogs is configured through the Event Setting window.
 Figure 11. 2 Event Setting Window
   Field  Field Description         Event          Event Name  Specify a unique key for the event. Once the event setting is saved, this event name can no longer be edited.        Event Type  Specify the type of event.        Event Title  Specify a title for this event type.          NOTE: The actual title shown on the event list of the widget is defined in the related widget.xml file. An example: <iw:item lang=”” id="IMLCExpiringLCs” value="Expiring Import LCs” readOnly="true” alias="elc”> </iw:item>           Module        Module  Select the related module from the dropdown list.        Description  This displays the description of the selected module.        Functions  This displays all the functions of the selected module with defined catalogs. Select the function with the relevant sub-catalog.          Date of Event        Sub Catalog ID  This displays the Id of the sub-catalog selected from the Catalog Description dropdown list (for Date of Event).        Catalog Description  From the dropdown list, select the sub-catalog to be used for displaying the records for this event. At runtime, the record can be subsequently accessed and processed through this sub-catalog.          Number of Event        Sub Catalog ID  This displays the Id of the sub-catalog selected from the Catalog Description dropdown list (for Number of Event).        Catalog Description  From the dropdown list, select the sub-catalog to be used for determining the number of records for this event.     Procedure
  To configure the event and sub-catalog settings for the Calendar Events widget:
    Do the following . . .       1. Access the Advance Setting sub-tab of the main Widget Setting tab (in the Widget Maintain function). Click on the Add button on the toolbar to add an event.            2. The Event Setting window is displayed. Define the event details, and click on the Save button.          3. Selected event details are shown in the grid of the Advance Setting sub-tab.          4. Add as many event types as required. NOTE: The Up and Down buttons can be used to arrange the order of events.          XML GENERATION: ADVANCED WIDGET SETTINGS Run the XML Generator function and select the Widget Maintain parameter type. Make sure to mark the widget profile in the XML Generator – Widget Maintain window that is displayed.          The XML files are generated on this path: [PARAMETER DRIVE]\CE_SYS\WIDGETS\CalendarEvents      Browser Settings
Before using the Calendar Events widget and modifying its properties:
  Log on the CE system as an Operator user; and
  Add the Calendar Events to the relevant tab as described in Chapter Nine > The Initial CE Landing Page with Widgets > Basic CE Widget Operations > Displaying Widgets.
   Using the Calendar Events Widget
  To use the Calendar Events widget:
    Do the following . . .       Accessing the Calendar Events Widget Click on the relevant tab to access the Calendar Events widget.            The Calendar Events widget window is divided into two sections: The calendar section The events section          NOTE: The Calendar Events widget provides a menu containing the Edit, Refresh, Maximize, Minimize, and Help window options. The Edit option is discussed in the following topic.          Arrow buttons are provided for navigating between months and years.          The days highlighted in red pertain to weekends.          The day selected by default pertains to the present day.          A flag indicates that there are events for the day.          The H marker indicates that the day is a holiday.          The days in gray pertain to days from a different month.          Adding an Event To add an event for a specific date, access the relevant month and year in the calendar section. NOTE: When there are no events or notes defined for a certain date, the events section displays this message: NO EVENTS.          Select the specific day.          Click on the Add icon at the bottom right corner of the widget window. NOTE: The Today button can be used to automatically go back to the current month and year page of the calendar.          The Calendar Events window is displayed.          Specify the event details, and click on the Save button. NOTE: To discard the information and go back to the main widget window, click on the Cancel button.          The system returns to the main Calendar Events window. On the calendar section, the day is marked with a flag. On the events section, a My Note link is added.          To view the notes for a specific date, select the specific date and click on the My Note link.          The Calendar Events window is displayed. The defined notes are shown.          Details can be added or edited as required. Click on the Save button. NOTE: To delete the current details, click on the Remove button.          Accessing the Events of a Day and Processing Transactions There are events for a day when it is marked with a flag. These events pertain to specific dates (e.g., expiring import LCs). In the calendar section, select the relevant date. The types of events for the day are then listed in the events section. For each event type, the number of records is also shown. EXAMPLE: There is one event type for December 22, 2016: Expiring Import LCs. There are twelve events for this event type.          Accessing All the Transactions for an Event Click on the link of the event type.          The system displays the transaction function related to the event type. Specifically, the event records are listed in the transaction function catalog. View or process the relevant transaction accordingly.          Accessing a Specific Transaction for an Event Click on the arrow button that corresponds to the relevant event type. The records for this event type are listed. Click on the specific record to be processed.          The system opens the record in the related transaction function. View or process the transaction accordingly. NOTE: These dates with events are marked with flags.       Title and Description

The Calendar Events window shows the current title and description of the widget.          NOTE: The Calendar Events window provides a menu with the Remove, Edit, Refresh, Maximize, Minimize, and Help window options. The Edit option is discussed in the previous topic.          4. Modify the Calendar Events title and description, and save the settings.          5. Click on the Save Changes button. NOTE: Every catalog is provided with buttons that are used for: Deleting the catalog from the list; and Changing the position of the catalog on the list.          5. The system returns to the main Criteria Search widget window.          The added function is now included in the Search For dropdown list.       Title and Description

The Criteria Search window shows the current title and description of the widget.          NOTE: The Criteria Search window provides a menu with the Remove, Edit, Refresh, Maximize, Minimize, and Help window options. The Edit option is discussed in the previous topic.          4.   Overview
  Parameter Settings
  Browser SEttings
  Overview
The Dashboard widget is used to access a specific catalog and subsequently view or process a record.
A catalog – inbox, product catalog, or function catalog – generally represents a specific type of transaction. Examples are LC transactions that are awaiting confirmation; Export Collection transactions that are awaiting authorization; and Import Collection transactions that have been rejected.
The availability of a catalog to the end-user is FAP-controlled: the user must have rights to the related function in order to view and access the corresponding records.
EXAMPLE:
The Import Letters of Credit – Awaiting Authorization catalog is included in the dashboard. If –
  There are 10 records for this catalog.
  The logged-on user has no access rights (FAP) to the related function.
  –The catalog is shown to the user but with no records.
Figure 13. 1 The Dashboard Widget
 NOTE: For a quick overview on how the Dashboard widget works, refer to the following discussion in this chapter:
  Browser Settings > Using the Dashboard Widget
 Parameter Settings
The parameter settings for the Dashboard widget are configured in the Widget Maintain function. This includes widget profile and advanced settings.
 Widget Profile Settings
  To configure the profile settings for the Dashboard widget:
    Do the following . . .       1. Run the Widget Maintain function from the Transaction Function group.            2. The Widget Maintain window is displayed. The window shows the following tabs: Widget Profile Widget Setting From the Widget Profile tab, click on the Add button on the toolbar.          3. The Widget Profile window is displayed. Specify the required details for the new widget. Make sure that the Widget Name is set to: Dashboard. Click on the Save button. NOTE: For details on the other profile settings, refer to: Chapter Nine > General Widget Parameter Settings > Widget Profile Settings          4. The newly created widget profile is displayed in the grid.          5. Click on the Synchronize to DB button in order to update the database with the newly defined widget settings.          6. Access the Widget Setting tab. This contains two sub-tabs: Generate Setting and Advance Setting.          7. From the Frame Work list in the Generate Setting tab, double-click on the newly created widget. Alternatively, select the widget and click on the Edit button on the toolbar.          8. A configuration window is displayed. To import predefined settings for the widget profile, click on the browse button for the Import Definition File option. NOTE: The Extend Definition File option is used for applying the settings of an existing widget profile to create a new widget profile. Refer to this discussion: Chapter Nine > General Widget Parameter Settings > Widget Definition File Extension          9. The Open dialog box is displayed. Browse for the widget.xml file – i.e., the widget definition file –from the relevant directory. NOTE: The widget.xml can be placed in any directory. It can also be modified directly and later imported through this same process. EXAMPLE: AppSrv01\CE_SYS\WIDGETS\Dashboard\widget.xml          10. The content of the imported file is shown on the configuration window. Check or modify the settings as required.          NOTE: To define whether or not multiple instances of the widget can be added to the same tab on the CE browser, set the allowInstanceContent attribute to either: false: Only one instance of the widget can be dragged and dropped to the same tab. true: Multiple instances of the widget can be dragged and dropped to the same tab.          NOTE: The number of rows and columns in the default layout of the dashboard is defined through the boardLayout attribute. The maximum number of rows and columns, on the other hand, is defined through the maxCapacity attribute.          When done with the settings, click on the Save button and close the window.          11. The system returns to the function window, which now shows the content of the imported definition file.          XML GENERATION: WIDGET PROFILE Run the XML Generator function and select the Widget Maintain parameter type. Make sure to mark the created widget profile in the XML Generator – Widget Maintain window that is displayed.          The XML file for the new widget profile is generated: [PARAMETER DRIVE]\CE_SYS\WIDGETS\Dashboard\widget.xml This is the updated version of the definition file that has been used for the widget profile: widget.xml. The settings only apply to this specific widget profile.       Advanced Widget Settings
  The advanced settings for the Dashboard widget involve selecting the specific catalogs to be utilized by the widget.
  Configuration
  These advanced Dashboard widget settings are configured through the Event Setting – Dashboard List window.
        Figure 13. 2 Event Setting – Dashboard List Window
   Field  Field Description         Dashboard List          Item Description  Specify the title to be used by the widget in displaying the records of a particular catalog.          EXAMPLE: Parameter setting – Item Description           Browser – Dashboard item         Catalog Type  Select from the dropdown list the type of catalog to be utilized by the Dashboard widget. Inbox Catalog Function Catalog Product Catalog NOTE: The Event Setting – Dashboard List window is altered according to the selected catalog type. Specifically, the Catalog List section is changed. Refer to the following Catalog List section.        (Catalog List)  Depending on the catalog type selected, this section displays one of the following types of lists:          Title/Item, for the Inbox Catalog type. Statistics catalogs are shown. (Statistics catalogs are defined through the Inbox function.)           Function Catalog, for the Function Catalog type. The modules, events, and transaction functions are shown. (Function catalogs are defined through Transaction Function.)           Products Catalog, for the Product Catalog type. The product groups, products, and functions are shown. (Product catalogs are defined through the Product Catalog function.)           To choose the catalog: For the Inbox Catalog type, select the specific Statistics catalog. The related Inbox Title and Item details are shown in the Field List section. For the Function Catalog and Product Catalog types, select the function which catalog is to be used. The Id, name, and description of the function are shown in the Field List section.        (Field List)  The grid shows the following details: Related Inbox Title and Item details – for the Inbox Catalog type Id, name, and description of the related transaction function – for Function Catalog and Product Catalog types NOTE: To remove the details here (and select another catalog), click on the Clear button.     Procedure
  To configure the advanced settings of the Dashboard widget:

  To use the Dashboard widget:
    Do the following . . .       1. Click on the relevant tab to access the Dashboard widget.                2. The Dashboard widget window displays the catalogs that are made available to this widget. For each catalog, the number of corresponding records is indicated and highlighted in red. NOTE: A catalog – inbox, product catalog, or function catalog – generally represents a specific type of transaction. The Dashboard widget provides a menu containing the Edit, Refresh, Maximize, Minimize, and Help window options. The Edit option is discussed in the following topic.          3. Changing the Dashboard Widget Properties
  The properties of the Dashboard widget can be modified in two ways:
   The Edit mode of the widget, for customizing how the widget works
  The Personalize link on the CE landing page, for changing the title and description of the widget
   Edit Mode
  To customize the functionalities of the Dashboard widget:
    Do the following . . .       1. Open the menu for the Dashboard widget and click on the Edit option. NOTE: The menu also provides the Refresh, Maximize, Minimize, and Help window options.            2. The Dashboard – Edit window is displayed. The Row Count and Column Count fields indicate the number of rows and columns to be allotted for the catalogs. The number of dropdown lists corresponds to the indicated number of rows and columns. Each dropdown list, in turn, typically corresponds to a catalog that is currently available in the widget.          NOTE: If no catalog is selected from a dropdown list, a corresponding area is allotted in the actual widget. Compare: The layout of the widget elements on Edit mode: 2 rows 2 columns Instead of 4 catalogs, only 2 are selected.          The layout on the actual widget shows only 2 dropdown lists. The available space, however, indicates that 2 more dropdown lists can be accommodated by the widget.          3. Select the number of rows from the Row Count dropdown list. NOTE: The maximum number of rows that can be selected depends on the setting in the widget configuration file.          4. Select the number of columns from the Column Count dropdown list. NOTE: The maximum number of columns that can be selected depends on the setting in the widget configuration file.          5. Dropdown lists that correspond to the indicated number of rows and columns are automatically displayed.          6. For each dropdown list, select the catalog to be made available in the Dashboard widget.          7. Click on the Save button to save the settings.          8. The system returns to the main Dashboard widget window.          The Dashboard reflects the catalog types in the defined layout. The number of records for each catalog type is indicated in red. The Dashboard window shows the current title and description of the widget.          NOTE: The Dashboard window provides a menu with the Remove, Edit, Refresh, Maximize, Minimize, and Help window options. The Edit option is discussed in the previous topic.          4. Modify the Dashboard title and description, and save the settings.          5. Click on the Save Changes button. NOTE: The Save and Discard links can be used to save and discard changes or actions made.          6. A confirmation message is displayed. Click on the Done button.          7.   The default way of opening and closing a product’s function list in the Main Menu widget is this:

  Overview

  Overview
The Notice widget is used for viewing the notification messages sent to the current (logged-on) user.
These messages may serve to:
  Inform the user of a completed transaction or process (e.g., a completed LC transaction)
  Notify a user of a pending process or action (e.g., an LC transaction that requires authorization)
  Alert the user of a transaction result or status (e.g., an LC transaction that has been rejected)
  In addition, these notifications serve as links for continuing the transaction process.
       Figure 16. 1 The Notice Widget

  Refer to the CE Supplementary Functions document for more information on generating widget notices.

Before using the Notification widget and modifying its properties:
  Log on the CE system as an Operator user; and
  Add the Notification widget to the relevant tab as described in Chapter Nine > The Initial CE Landing Page with Widgets > Basic CE Widget Operations > Displaying Widgets.
   Using the Notice Widget
  To use the Notice widget:
    Do the following . . .       Accessing the Notice Widget Click on the relevant tab to access the Notice widget.            The Notice widget provides: Buttons and options: Labels, Filter, More, Trash The total number of notifications Links for directly accessing a transaction or notification Open More link, for displaying more transaction records          NOTE: The Notice widget provides a menu containing the Edit, Refresh, Maximize, Minimize, and Help window options. The Edit option is discussed in the following topic.          Handling a Notification To view or process a transaction directly, click on the appropriate notification.          The Task Detail page is displayed. Basic information on the transaction or notification is provided. To continue processing the transaction, click on the Process button.          The relevant transaction function is displayed. Process the transaction accordingly. NOTE: Notifications can also be viewed and subsequently processed through the View Notification Detail function of the Notification View product.          Displaying All Notifications To display all the notifications, click on the Open More link on the bottom right corner of the window. NOTE: The total number of notifications is indicated on the upper right corner of the window.          A page is displayed listing all the notifications.          The Read Status dropdown list can be used for filtering the types of notifications to be displayed: All, Read, or Unread. Select the relevant option and click on the Filter option. Pagination options are also provided for navigating between pages of notifications. To view or process a transaction, click on the notification link. Refer to the preceding Handling a Notification section. NOTE: To display all the records again – read and unread – click on the Reset option.          Labeling a Notification Mark the specific notification and click on the Labels button. A list of available labels is displayed; select the relevant label. NOTE: Labels are maintained in the Label product.          The specific notification is now designated with the selected label. NOTE: To remove the label of a notification: Select the notification; and Open the Labels dropdown list and select the same label.          Filtering Notifications To display only specific notifications, click on the Filter button. Select the type from the list that is displayed: All, Read, or Unread. NOTE: Notifications may be further filtered based on its read status and date. Refer to the succeeding Filtering Notifications discussion in this chapter for more details.          Marking Notifications as Read or Unread Mark the specific notification and click on the More button. Select the relevant option from the list that is displayed: Mark as Read or Mark as Unread. NOTE: Unread notifications are highlighted in gray.          Deleting Notifications To delete a notification, select it and click on the Trash icon.         Filtering Notifications Notifications in the Notice widget may be filtered based on their read status and the date on which the notification has been received. To do this, the catalog setting of the View Notice Details function must first be modified. Configuration Modify the View Notice Detail function catalog condition as: Generate the XML file for the function catalog. Modify the following files. Criteria_Notification.jsp Path: [CEWeb.war folder]\CSBANK\US\WEB\CATA <%– /** * $Id: Criteria_Party.jsp,v 1.5 2009/03/19 11:19:38 john.zhong Exp $ * * @module: Standing Module (STAN) * @function: View Notice Detail */ –%> <%@ taglib uri = “/MLGTAG” prefix = “MLG”%> <table> <tr> <td class="FldLabel”>Read Status</td> <td colspan="2”><select name="OP1” id="OP1” class="CHAR_O” style="width:180px”> <option value=”” selected="true”>All</option> <option value="T”>Read</option> <option value="F”>Unread</option> </select></td> </tr> <tr class="addCrtiTempClass1”> <td variableGrp="OP2,OP3” class="FldLabel INSERT_DATE_INDEX” desc="AddDate”>Add Date</td> <td><label>From </label><input name="OP2” type="text” class="DATE_O FROM_DATE” id="OP2” size="20” maxlength="20”></td> <td><label>To </label><input name="OP3” type="text” class="DATE_O TO_DATE” id="OP3” size="20” maxlength="20”></td> </tr> </table>      notification.js

  Transaction Processing
   Log on to the CE Utility. In the Notice widget, click on the Open More link.
  All available notification records are listed. Additional filter option fields are shown. Specify the Read Status and From and To dates. Click on the Filter link.
  The relevant notification records are shown based on the defined filter criteria. Click on the Reset link.
  All defined filter criteria are removed and all the notification records are shown.
   Changing the Notice Widget Properties
  The properties of the Notice widget can be modified in two ways:
   The Edit mode of the widget, for customizing how the widget works
  The Personalize link on the CE landing page, for changing the title and description of the widget
Edit Mode
To customize the functionalities of the Notice widget:
     Do the following . . .       1. Open the menu for the Notice widget and click on the Edit option. NOTE: The menu also provides the Refresh, Maximize, Minimize, and Help window options.            2. The Notice – Edit window is displayed.          3. From the Show Notifications in Widget dropdown list, select the number of notifications to be shown on the Notice widget. Click on the Save button to save the setting. NOTE: The default number of notifications that can be displayed on the widget depends on the setting in the widget configuration file.          4. The system returns to the main Notice widget window. The widget only lists the defined number of notifications. To view all the notifications, click on the Open More link.       Title and Description
  Through the Personalize link, the title and description of the Notification widget can be modified. The title appears on the title bar of the widget window. The description, on the other hand, appears as a tooltip.
    Do the following . . .       1. Click on the Personalize link.            2. The Personalize page is displayed.          3. The Notice window shows the current title and description of the widget.          NOTE: The Notice window provides a menu with the Remove, Edit, Refresh, Maximize, Minimize, and Help window options. The Edit option is discussed in the previous topic.          4. Modify the Notice title and description, and save the settings.          5. Click on the Save Changes button. NOTE: The Save and Discard links can be used to save and discard changes or actions made.          6. A confirmation message is displayed. Click on the Done button.          7. The system returns to the landing page.          The Notice widget reflects the new title and description.      The Quick Access Widget
  Overview
  Parameter SEttings
  Browser SEttings
  Overview
The Quick Access function is used for directly accessing frequently run functions.
The availability of a function to the end-user is FAP-controlled: the user must have the relevant function access rights.
       Figure 17. 1 The Quick Access Widget
 NOTE: For a quick overview on how the Quick Access widget works, refer to the following discussion in this chapter:
  Browser Settings > Using the Quick Access Widget
 Parameter Settings
The parameter settings for the Quick Access widget are configured in the Widget Maintain function. This includes widget profile and advanced settings.
 Widget Profile Settings
  To configure the profile settings for the Quick Access widget:
    Do the following . . .       1. Run the Widget Maintain function from the Transaction Function group.            2. The Widget Maintain window is displayed. The window shows the following tabs: Widget Profile Widget Setting From the Widget Profile tab, click on the Add button on the toolbar.          3. The Widget Profile window is displayed. Specify the required details for the new widget. Make sure that the Widget Name is set to: QuickAccess. Click on the Save button. NOTE: For details on the other profile settings, refer to: Chapter Nine > General Widget Parameter Settings > Widget Profile Settings          4. The newly created widget profile is displayed in the grid.          5. Click on the Synchronize to DB button in order to update the database with the newly defined widget settings.          6. Access the Widget Setting tab. This contains two sub-tabs: Generate Setting and Advance Setting.          7. From the Frame Work list in the Generate Setting tab, double-click on the newly created widget. Alternatively, select the widget and click on the Edit button on the toolbar.          8. A configuration window is displayed. To import predefined settings for the widget profile, click on the browse button for the Import Definition File option. NOTE: The Extend Definition File option is used for applying the settings of an existing widget profile to create a new widget profile. Refer to this discussion: Chapter Nine > General Widget Parameter Settings > Widget Definition File Extension          9. The Open dialog box is displayed. Browse for the widget.xml file – i.e., the widget definition file –from the relevant directory. NOTE: The widget.xml can be placed in any directory. It can also be modified directly and later imported through this same process. EXAMPLE: AppSrv01\CE_SYS\WIDGETS\QuickAccess\widget.xml          10. The content of the imported file is shown on the configuration window. Check or modify the settings as required.          NOTE: To define whether or not multiple instances of the widget can be added to the same tab on the CE browser, set the allowInstanceContent attribute to either: false: Only one instance of the widget can be dragged and dropped to the same tab. true: Multiple instances of the widget can be dragged and dropped to the same tab.          The default number of functions to be shown on the widget is defined through the listCount attribute.          When done with the settings, click on the Save button and close the window.          11. The system returns to the function window, which now shows the content of the imported definition file.          XML GENERATION: WIDGET PROFILE Run the XML Generator function and select the Widget Maintain parameter type. Make sure to mark the created widget profile in the XML Generator – Widget Maintain window that is displayed.          The XML file for the new widget profile is generated: [PARAMETER DRIVE]\CE_SYS\WIDGETS\QuickAccess\widget.xml This is the updated version of the definition file that has been used for the widget profile: widget.xml. The settings only apply to this specific widget profile.          NOTE: The options for the number of functions to be shown on the widget are defined through the options attributes in this file: CE.ear\CEWeb.war\widgets\QuickAccess\quickaccess.js       Advanced Widget Settings
  The advanced settings for the Quick Access widget involve selecting the specific functions to be utilized by the widget.
  Configuration
  These advanced Quick Access widget settings are configured through the Event Setting – Quick Access List window.
        Figure 17. 2 Event Setting – Quick Access List Window
   Field  Field Description         Quick Access List          Product Catalog List  This section lists the available product groups, products, and functions. Open the product group and product, and select the relevant function. Click on the Add button to include it as one of the functions to be utilized by the Quick Access widget. The selected function is also added to the Function List. To add all the functions from a product, select the product and click on the >> button. The functions under this product are added to the Function List.        (Function List)  This section lists the Id, name, description, and path (product) of the selected functions. NOTE: Use the Clear and Clear All buttons to remove functions from the list.     Procedure
  To configure the advanced settings of the Quick Access widget:
    Do the following . . .       1. Access the Advance Setting sub-tab of the main Widget Setting tab (in the Widget Maintain function). Click on the Add button on the toolbar to add an event.            2. The Event Setting – Quick Access List window is displayed. Select the relevant functions to be utilized by the Quick Access widget.          Click on the Save button when done.          3. Selected function details are shown in the grid of the Advance Setting sub-tab. Add as many functions as required.          XML GENERATION: ADVANCED WIDGET SETTINGS Run the XML Generator function and select the Widget Maintain parameter type. Make sure to mark the widget profile in the XML Generator – Widget Maintain window that is displayed.          The XML files are generated on this path: [PARAMETER DRIVE]\CE_SYS\WIDGETS\QuickAccess      Browser Settings

  The properties of the Quick Access widget can be modified in two ways:
   The Edit mode of the widget, for customizing how the widget works
  The Personalize link on the CE landing page, for changing the title and description of the widget
Edit Mode
To customize the functionalities of the Quick Access widget:
     Do the following . . .       1. Open the menu for the Quick Access widget and click on the Edit option. NOTE: The menu also provides the Refresh, Maximize, Minimize, and Help window options.            2. The Quick Access – Edit window is displayed.          3. To change the number of functions that can be shown on the Quick Access widget, select the number from The Total Count dropdown list. NOTE: The maximum number of functions that can be displayed on the widget depends on the setting in the widget configuration file.          4. To add a function to be displayed on the Quick Access widget, select it from the Select to Add dropdown list. The function is automatically added in the function list.          Up to the indicated number of functions can be added to the list.          NOTE: Every function is provided with buttons that are used for: Deleting the function from the list; and Changing the position of the function on the list.          5. Click on the Save button to save the settings.          6. The system returns to the main Quick Access widget window. The widget reflects the selected functions, the number of which complies with the defined number of functions to be displayed.       Title and Description
  Through the Personalize link, the title and description of the Quick Access widget can be modified. The title appears on the title bar of the widget window. The description, on the other hand, appears as a tooltip.
    Do the following . . .       1. Click on the Personalize link.            2. The Personalize page is displayed.          3. The Quick Access window shows the current title and description of the widget.          NOTE: The Quick Access window provides a menu with the Remove, Edit, Refresh, Maximize, Minimize, and Help window options. The Edit option is discussed in the previous topic.          4. Modify the Quick Access title and description, and save the settings.          5. Click on the Save Changes button. NOTE: The Save and Discard links can be used to save and discard changes or actions made.          6. A confirmation message is displayed. Click on the Done button.          7. The system returns to the landing page.          The Quick Access widget reflects the new title and description.      The Recent Functions Widget

  Overview
The Statistics widget is used to display transaction statistics using graphical representations such as a line, bar, or a pie chart.
It can be configured for two purposes:
  Displaying transaction statistics based on criteria defined through an SQL query. The statistics to be displayed on the widget is the result of the query. This is known as the viewData widget type.
  Displaying statistics of a specific function. In this configuration, the Statistics widget can be clicked, and redirects the user to the related function. This is known as the jumpFunction widget type.
  The availability of the statistics to the end-user is may be FAP-controlled: the user must have rights to the related function in order to view and access the corresponding records.
The parameters for the Statistics widget are configured through the following:
  widget.xml file
  statistics.xml file
  Widget Profile settings (for jumpFunction widget type)
  Parameter Settings for viewData Widget Type
 Widget.xml File
  The widget.xml file is used to define whether the Statistics widget is for viewing only or if it is to provide the user the option to directly access a related function after viewing information from the widget.
  This file is located in the [Parameter Drive]:\CE_SYS\WIDGETS\Statistics folder.
  If it is to be used for viewing only, the value of the widgetType parameter must be set to viewData.
  Otherwise, the value must be set to jumpFunction.
  NOTE: After modifying the widget.xml file, the application server must be restarted.
        Figure 22. 1 Statistics Widget: Widget.xml File
 Statistics.xml File
  The statistics.xml file is used to define the criteria for the information to be displayed in the Statistics widget.
 It contains the following elements:
   Concept  Description       <level1>  This element is the main container where the settings for the widget are defined.          <sqlList>  This element is where the query or queries are specfied. It has two attributes: NeedFAPCheck: This is used to define whether or not the query requires Function Assignment Permission (FAP) check. Its value can be either of the following: T – If this option is specified, the system adds conditions to the query to conduct an FAP check. If the current user does not have the required FAP for the module specified in the query, the query results for the module are not shown on the widget. F – If this option is specified, the system executes the defined query directly. MultiTable: This is used to define whether or not the query is to be executed for multiple tables in the database. Its value can be either of the following: T – If this option is specified, the query involves multiple tables. The alias of the main table must be set to A. If the value of NeedFAPCheck is T, the system only supports a Master, Event Master, or TRX_INBOX table to be the main table. F – If this option is specified, the query is for a single database table only.            <sql>  Inside the <sqlList> element, there can be several <sql> elements. Each <sql> element defines a set of queries. It has two attributes: seriesName – This is used to define the legend name for the data group. If its value is not defined, the system sets it using the format [chart name][chart number]. When the legend name is clicked, the curve for the related data group can be hidden or shown. dsTyp – This is used to define the data source where the query retrieves the data. The data source options are the following: T – This option refers to the transaction data source. It is the default value. A – This option refers to an archiving data source. B – This option refers to a backup data source. The system provides placeholders for the uncertain values in the query. Data Source: $DS is used for the transaction schema. (e.g. $DS.TRX_INBOX) Field Value: the following placeholders are provided for the fields’ value in query condition. The system sets the exact value according to currently logged on user. NOTE: Setting the security schema or tablespace (e.g. CEUSER) as a data source for a query is not supported.          <xAxis>  This element is used to define the description for the query result on the X-axis (for bar or line charts). Inside it, there can be several <desc> elements to define the description in different languages. The default description is defined using the <desc lang=”"> element. If two results have the same description, the results are separated by a comma. If the description is not defined, the system uses the query result directly as the description. Example: <xAxis> <desc lang=”"> <![CDATA[P,T:Awaiting Authorization; A,S:Authorised; R:Rejected;]]> </desc> <desc lang="CNS”><![CDATA[P,T:待授权; A,S:已授权; R:拒绝]]> </desc> </xAxis> NOTE: A colon (:) or semicolon (;) is not allowed in the description.        <series>  This element is used to define the description for the seriesName legend name in the <sql> element. Inside it, there can be several <desc> elements to define the description in different languages. The default description is defined using the <desc lang=”">. If the description is not defined, the system uses the seriesName value in <sql> element directly. Example: <series> <desc lang=”"> <![CDATA[IMLC:Import LC;OWGT:Guarantees;]]> </desc> <desc lang="CNS”> <![CDATA[IMLC:进口信用证;OWGT:担保;]]> </desc> </series> NOTE: A colon (:) or semicolon (;) is not allowed in the description.     Configuration
    Do the following . . .       1. Open the relevant widget.xml file. This file is located in the [Parameter Drive]:\CE_SYS\WIDGETS\Statistics folder.            2. Set the value of the widgetType parameter to viewData. Once done, save the changes.          3. Open the statistics.xml file. This file is located in the [Parameter Drive]:\CE_SYS\WIDGETS\Statistics folder.          4. Provide the values for the following parameters: <sqlList NeedFAPCheck> <sqlList MultiTable> <sql seriesName> <sql dsType> <xAxis><desc lang> <series><desc lang> Once done, save the changes. NOTE: Refer to Chapter 22: Statistics.xml File for more information on the parameters in the statistics.xml file.          EXAMPLE: Multiple Queries for One Data Set In this example, there are two sets of data; IMLC and OWGT. For each data set, there are three queries: Awaiting Authorization Authorised Rejected The queries for the data set must match the descriptions defined in the X-axis in order for the system to correctly map the query result to its corresponding description.          EXAMPLE: Single Query for One Data Set In this example, only the IMLC data set is defined, and only a single query, LC_CCY information, is specified for the data set. No description is provided for the X-axis parameter; therefore, the system uses the query result directly as the descriptions for the X-axis.          EXAMPLE: Multiple Table Query In this example, specified SQL statement executes the query to multiple tables in the database. When querying to multiple tables, the value of the MultiTable attribute must be set to T and the alias of the main table must be set to A. If the FAP check is required, the system adds conditions based on the main table’s alias (e.g. A.C_UNIT_CODE)          EXAMPLE: Legend Names To define the legend name for a data group, two methods can be used: seriesName – This is used to define the legend name for the data group. If its value is not defined, the system sets it using the format [chart name][chart number]. This element is used to define the description for the seriesName legend name in the <sql> element. Inside it, there can be several <desc> elements to define the description in different languages. The default description is defined using the <desc lang=”">. If the description is not defined, the system uses the seriesName value in <sql> element directly.          EXAMPLE: Multi-language Configuration To enable the multi-language feature for the widget, specify the langage code in the <desc lang> attribute of the <xAxis> and <series> elements. The system checks on the languages defined in the <desc lang> attributes. If the current system language matches a language defined in the <desc lang> attribute, the relevant language is displayed in the Statistics widget.      Parameter Settings for jumpFunction Widget Type
 jumpFunction.xml File
  The jumpFunction.xml file is used to define the functions to which the user is to be redirected when the Statistics widget is clicked.
 It contains the following elements:
   Concept  Description       <level1>  This element is the main container where the settings for the widget are defined. It contains three sub-elements: <functionGroup>, <xAxis> and <fieldInfo>.          <functionGroup>  This element is where the related functions are defined. It contains the <functionID> element        <functionID>  This element is where a group of related transaction function IDs are specified. The IDs are separated by comma. It contains an attribute: seriesName – This is used to define the legend name for the data group. If its value is not defined, the system sets it using the format [chart name][chart number]. When the legend name is clicked, the curve for the related data group can be hidden or shown. NOTE: Only functions with a catalog are supported in the jumpFunction type of the Statistics widget.        <xAxis>  This element is used to define the description for the function on the X-axis (for bar or line charts). Inside it, there can be several <desc> elements to define the description in different languages. The default description is defined using the <desc lang=”"> element. If the description is not defined, the transaction function as the description. The value must be set up if functions in the <functionID> group have thesame description (e.g., function IMLC Authorize and EXLC Authorize have the same function description. In this case the value “Authorise Transaction” must be set up). Example: <xAxis> <desc lang=”"><![CDATA[IMLC;EXLC;IMCO;EXCO;IWGT;OWGT]]> </desc> <desc lang="CNS”><![CDATA[进口信用证;出口信用证;进口托收;出口托收;进口担保;出口担保]]> </desc> </xAxis> NOTE: A colon (:) or semicolon (;) is not allowed in the description.        <series>  This element is used to define the description for the seriesName legend name in the <functionID> element. Inside it, there can be several <desc> elements to define the description in different languages. The default description is defined using the <desc lang=”">. If the description is not defined, the system uses the seriesName value in <functionID> element directly. Example: <series> <desc lang=”"> <![CDATA[AUTH:Authorise Transaction;]]></desc> <desc lang="CNS”><![CDATA[AUTH:授权;]]></desc> </series> NOTE: A colon (:) or semicolon (;) is not allowed in the description.     Configuration
    Do the following . . .       1. Run the Widget Maintain function from the Transaction Function group.            2. The Widget Maintain window is displayed. The window shows the following tabs: Widget Profile Widget Setting From the Widget Profile tab, click on the Add button on the toolbar.          3. The Widget Profile window is displayed. Specify the required details for the new widget. Make sure that the Widget Name is set to: StatisticsFunc. Click on the Save button. NOTE: For details on the other profile settings, refer to: Chapter Nine > General Widget Parameter Settings > Widget Profile Settings          4. The newly created widget profile is displayed in the grid.          5. Click on the Synchronize to DB button in order to update the database with the newly defined widget settings.          6. Access the Widget Setting tab. This contains two sub-tabs: Generate Setting and Advance Setting.          7. From the Frame Work list in the Generate Setting tab, double-click on the newly created widget. Alternatively, select the widget and click on the Edit button on the toolbar.          8. A configuration window is displayed. Select the Extend Definition File option to apply the settings of an existing widget profile to create a new widget profile. From the corresponding dropdown menu, select the relevant definition file. NOTE: Refer to this discussion: Chapter Nine > General Widget Parameter Settings > Widget Definition File Extension          9. The content of the selected file is shown on the configuration window. The value of the widgetType parameter must be set to jumpFunction.          NOTE: To define whether or not multiple instances of the widget can be added to the same tab on the CE browser, set the allowInstanceContent attribute to either: false: Only one instance of the widget can be dragged and dropped to the same tab. true: Multiple instances of the widget can be dragged and dropped to the same tab.          When done with the settings, click on the Save button and close the window.          10. The system returns to the function window, which now shows the content of the imported definition file.          XML GENERATION: Run the XML Generator function and select the Widget Maintain parameter type. Make sure to mark the created widget profile in the XML Generator – Widget Maintain window that is displayed.          The XML file for the new widget profile is generated: [PARAMETER DRIVE]\CE_SYS\WIDGETS\StatisticsFunc\widget.xml This is the updated version of the definition file that has been used for the widget profile: widget.xml. The settings only apply to this specific widget profile.          11. NOTE: Refer to Chapter Twenty-two: jumpFunction.xml for a detailed discussion on the jumpFunction.xml file.      Widget Graphic Settings
Different types of graphical representations can be used to display information on the Statistics widget. The following types of charts are provided:
  line graph
  bar graph
  pie chart
  The system also provides an option to display the details in tabular format below the chart.
These features are configured through the widget.xml file that is located in the [Parameter Drive]: \CE_SYS\WIDGETS\Statistics folder.
 NOTE: After modifying the widget.xml file, the application server must be restarted.
    Do the following . . .       1. Open the relevant widget.xml file.            2. To display the details using a line graph, set the value of the graphType parameter to line. Once done, save the changes.          EXAMPLE: When the Statistics widget is accessed in the browser, information is illustrated through a line graph.          3. To display the details using a bar graph, set the value of the graphType parameter to bar. To display the vertical bars, set the value of the isLie attribute to F. Otherwise, set its value to T to display horizontal bars. Once done, save the changes.          EXAMPLE: When the Statistics widget is accessed in the browser, information is illustrated through a bar graph. Depending on the value of the isLie parameter in the widget.xml file, the bars may be displayed vertically or horizontally.          4. To display the details using a pie chart, set the value of the graphType parameter to pie. Once done, save the changes.          EXAMPLE: When the Statistics widget is accessed in the browser, information is illustrated through a pie chart. If more than one data set is available, a dropdown list is provided to select the data set to be displayed.          5. To show the details in tabular format, set the value of the showTable parameter to T.          EXAMPLE: If the value of the showTable parameter is set to T, a table containing the statistics is displayed below the graph or chart.      Browser Settings

  Log on the CE system as an Operator user; and
  Add the Statistics widget to the relevant tab as described in Chapter Nine > The Initial CE Landing Page with Widgets > Basic CE Widget Operations > Displaying Widgets.

The Statistics widget window displays the system transaction statistics or function statistics, depending on the settings defined for the widgetType parameter. NOTE: Refer to the following discussions for configuring the details to be displayed in the Statistics widget: Chapter Twenty-two: Statistics.xml File Chapter Twenty-two: jumpFunction.xml File            3. If the value of the widgetType parameter is set to jumpFunction, the data point can be clicked to proceed to the catalog of the related function.          4. The system displays the actual catalog screen. Process the relevant transaction accordingly.      Special Widget Features
  SETTING WIDGET COLUMNS
  DEFINING THE WIDGETS CSS FILE BY REGION OR BANK
  Setting Widget Columns
When personalizing widgets, the number of columns on which the widgets are to be displayed in the CE landing page, as well as the alignment of cross column widgets, may be configured.
 Initial Setting
  To enable the widget column setting feature, the following settings must first be configured:
   SQL scripts
 Error Codes     SQL Scripts
  The following SQL scripts must first be run in the database to add 2 columns in the CEUSER.SEC_WIDGET_LAYOUT table.
 (Start code)
 INSERT INTO CEUSER.SEC_WIDGET_ INSERT INTO CEUSER.SEC_WIDGET_LAYOUT(C_LAYOUT_ID,C_LAYOUT_NAME,C_FILE_NAME,C_DEFAULT_FLAG,C_RUN_STATUS) values (‘8AA7E5236BBB7CBA016BBB84DC610005’,‘column2’,‘layout’,‘N’,‘A’);
  LAYOUT(C_LAYOUT_ID,C_LAYOUT_NAME,C_FILE_NAME,C_DEFAULT_FLAG,C_RUN_STATUS) values (‘8AA7E5236BFD69D9016BFD870B0C0010’,‘column4’,‘layout’,‘N’,‘A’);
  COMMIT;
  (End code)
  Error Codes
  Through the Error Handling function, add or modify the 000135 (the default error message for unexpected exceptions) and 000549 error codes.
  The following table shows examples, which can be modified according to project requirements.
    Error Key Error Code Error Message Recommended Action Error Level Variable     SYSTEM 000135 Unexpected exception. Please contact us for help. ERROR N/A   SYSTEM 000549 Please remove extra widget(s) before reducing the column. N/A WARNING N/A     Add or modify the error codes 000135 and 000549 in the Error Handling function of the CE Utility.                       Generate the XML files for the Error Handling parameter. The generated files are stored on the following path:
[Parameter Folder]\CE_SYS
[Parameter Folder]\CE_SYS\ERROR\DEFAULT
          Increase or Decrease the Number of Widget Columns
  When personalizing widget settings, the number of columns on which widgets are to be arranged in may be defined.
  Widgets may be displayed in either 2, 3, or 4 columns. To increase columns, the additional columns must be added, and the user may add or move widget instances. However, when reducing columns, the user must first move or remove extra widget instances that are included in the column to be deleted.
  Column settings are applied in all widget tabs.
  NOTE: In CE version 3.3.0, widgets may be displayed in 3 columns only.
  Configuration
  To be able to increase or decrease the number of widget columns, configurations must be made to the following CEWeb.war files.
 Files to be added
  column4.css
  layout.jsp

    Do the Following …         Increase Widget Columns          1. Log on to the CE system as an operator user. In the CE landing page, click on the Personalize link.          2. In the Personalize page, the selected widgets are shown. In this example, the number of widget columns is set to 2.          3. In the Column Number field, select 3 from the dropdown list.          4. An additional column is added on the right side of the widgets area. A message is shown indicating that all changes are saved.          5. Add the relevant widgets on the newly added column (e.g., Dashboard, Quick Access, Exchange Rate) A message is shown indicating that modifications are not yet saved. Click on the Save link or the Save Changes button.          6. A confirmation message is displayed indicating that all changes are saved. Click on the Done button.          7. In the CE landing page, the widgets are arranged in 3 columns based on the personalized setting.            Decrease Widget Columns        1. Log on to the CE system as an operator user. In the CE landing page, click on the Personalize link.          2. In the Personalize page, the selected widgets are shown. In this example, the number of widget columns is set to 4.          3. In the Column Number field, select 2 from the dropdown list.          4. As the number of columns are to be reduced from 4 to 2, an error message is shown, which indicates that the widgets included in the columns to be removed must first be deleted before reducing the number of columns.          5. To remove widgets on the 2 right-most columns, click on the menu button on the upper right corner of each widget. Select the Remove option from the dropdown list. Click on the Save Changes button.          6. In the Column Number field, select 2. The widgets are then arranged into 2 columns. Save the changes and click on the Done button.          7. In the CE landing page, the widgets are arranged in 2 columns based on the personalized setting.       Left Align Cross Column Widgets
  Configurations may be made to enable cross column widgets, which occupy 2 columns on the page, to always be displayed on the left side portion of the screen by default when personalizing widget settings.
  NOTE: Refer to the Adjusting Widget Layouts discussion in Chapter 9 for more information on cross column widgets.
  Configuration
  To enable the cross column widget left alignment feature, the following settings must be configured:
   Modify the layout.jsp file that is located in the following path:
[CEWeb.war Folder]\widgets\framework\layouts\column2

    Do the Following …       1. Log on to the CE system as an operator user. In the CE landing page, click on the Personalize link.            2. In the Personalize page, the selected widgets are shown. In this example, the number of widget columns is set to 3. The cross column widget in this example is the Inbox widget, which is automatically aligned to the left.          3. Add widget columns as required through the Column Number field. In this example, select 4 in the Column Number field to increase the column number from 3 to 4.          4. A new column is added on the right portion of the widgets area. A message is shown indicating that all changes are saved. The cross column widget remains aligned to the left.          5. Add the relevant widgets on the newly added column. A message is shown indicating that modifications are not yet saved. Click on the Save link or the Save Changes button.          6. A confirmation message is displayed indicating that all changes are saved. Click on the Done button.          7. In the CE landing page, the widgets are arranged in 4 columns based on the personalized setting. To decrease widget column numbers, click on the Personalize link.          8. To reduce the column number, the widgets set in the column to be deleted must first be removed or moved to a different column. Remove the relevant widgets and then reduce the column from 4 to 3 through the Column Number field.          NOTE: If the column number is reduced while widgets are still existing in the column to be removed, an error message is shown.          9. A confirmation message is shown once all the changes made are saved. Click on the Done button.          10. In the CE landing page, the widgets are arranged in 3 columns based on the personalized setting.       Right Align Cross Column Widgets
  Configurations may be made to enable cross column widgets, which occupy 2 columns on the page, to always be displayed on the right side portion of the screen by default when personalizing widget settings.
  NOTE:
  i. Refer to the Adjusting Widget Layouts discussion in Chapter 9 for more information on Cross Column Widgets.
  ii. The right align cross column widgets feature is only applied for 3 or 4-column widget settings.
  Configuration
  To enable the right aligned cross widget column feature, the following configuration must be made:
  For 3 Widget Columns
  Refer to the Adjusting Widget Layouts > Layout.jsp file discussion for the updates to be made on the layout.jsp file for 3 widget column setting.
  For 4 Widget Columns
  Create a backup copy of the layout.jsp file located in the following path:
  [CEWeb.war folder]\widgets\framework\layouts\column4
  Create a new file with the same name (i.e., layout.jsp) in this same path with the following content:
